review_body: Hi have stayed a few time now at the Apa Hotel, The staff every time seem so welcoming on arrival, Rooms I have always had cheap rooms but a large bed, TV, Internet, Tea and Coffee, Full Bath Room, The only bit is i have Fly luggage so the case is sometimes in the way, but not an issue as its a room, tidy, comfy and in a great location, quiet area but 5 mins walk up the road and you in a busy night time location, Breakfast is traditional buffet, Japanese and a little western choices, tea, coffee, juice etc.Restaurant was good had a meal and was not expensive and tasty Hotel for all Types Solo, Business, Couple and Family

I stayed here for one night after arriving at Haneda from US. I loved there big onsen bath located at B1. After a long flight, it helped me to feel alive again. The room was small but clears and convenient to use. Bed was comfortable. I did not hear much noise either. For the price I paid (6000 yen per night) I have No complains. There are so many restaurants, bars and convenience stores near by.

The location was close to a small station and easily walkable to the main Shinjuku station. Plenty of food and shopping in short walking distance too. The onsen was a bonus. The tubs were pretty small but I was there at an offpeak period so there weren't many people. The room was tiny as the standard by Tokyo standards but I had room enough to move around and have my suitcase open. I got breakfast with the room and it was adequate but not much of a selection and I would've been better served just buying breakfast outside.

We did not like our stay at this APA Hotel at all. Because of an outside temperature of 11 degrees airco was switched off. However rooms are very small/tiny and we were with 2 people taking showers, moving around etc. Consequently the room got hotter and hotter to the point in the morning it was very, very unpleasant. In the morning the sun was shining on the windows and outside temperature was above 14 degrees. One can imagine how hot it got in there. When checking out the frontdesk staff was incredibly lackluster and NOT interested in dealing with the issue or giving a professional response. It was a staff attitude which you rarely experience in Japan. Oe can only assume it might be the result of inadequate personnel management by hotel management.

We did 3 nights here, the place was clean, comfortable and easy (but VERY small - not an issue for us but some people may not like it). Staff very friendly at checkin/out and in the breakfast. Fresh eggs and omelettes are great! Excellent location, have everything you need in walking distance. For a small room the bathroom was quite good aswell.

great value and comfortable to travel along tokyo walk by 10 mins to JR. Bedroom is clean and nice facility in room.Quiet and feel free at night.reception at lobby is good communication excellent work.Will come again next time.

To get there, from the Shinjuku Station use the South Exit, turn left and walk for about 10 minutes, then turn left at the start of the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden entrance and then turn right. It takes about 10-15 minutes walk from the Shinjuku station. Hotel is one block over from the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden (closed on Mondays).Overall the hotel is quite new, small lobby and is generally quite clean. Has an Onsen which I did not use (didn't want to frighten the locals).They only provide water after the first cleaning so the room will be empty whan you arrive. The rooms are very small and clean.The shower does not allow you to adjust the flow of water so it is set at very strong and will often flood the floor if you done set the screen properly.Quite good value being in Tokyo and would stay again.

Great value hotel for single travelers. The hotel is kind of a 15-20 mins walk from JR shinjuku station but I only need to use JR station on the days of arrival and departure. Otherwise the hotel is conveniently located close to Shinjuku gyoenmae and Shinjuku Sanchome station. Another benefit of this hotel is it’s very quiet at night, unlike other inexpensive hotels near kabukicho where you can encounter LOTS of pimps on your way back to the hotel every night. I did take others’ recommendation to book a double bed and the room size is ok enough for me to open up my one 24 in luggage. Overall a nice hotel and the hot tub access is the icing on the cake. Would definitely come back again.

While room is small, is okay for one person, I have no complains. The facilities and location are nice. Good bed, good shower and toilet. Quick service. Excellent location just right next to everything, and less than 10 mins walk to central shinjuku station. Pillows are thin as a towel. The internet was not working on a weekend (hotel was full). After warming up the room the A/C won't switch to cooling, so you basically need to open your door to cool your room otherwise it will be too hot. With this warning you'll be fine.

Great staff, love the onsen, rooms are a little small but its central tokyo what do you expect . smoking rooms are a bonus. i really like the freshness burger next door best fast food ever. stayed here twice

I spent 10 nights here. I have stayed at other properties within the APA chain, and they are all very similar. This hotel is a 10 minute walk from Shinjuku station (Take the East exit, and walk straight east along Shinjuku-Chome Street), or a 2-minute walk from (M10) Shinjuku-Gyonmae Station (use Entrance 1 or 3). Family Mart and 7-11 and pharmacy are steps away. There's also a small grocery store next to 7-11 where you can buy fruit, as well as lots of restaurants within a short walking distance.Rooms are small, but has almost everything you need. There is a free onsen in the basement (from 6am to 12am). Many of the floors are smoke-free.They provide a yukata robe (changed daily) and slippers. Small bar fridge, kettle, hairdryer and all toiletries except body lotion, are provided. However, there is no room for any unpacking and storage of clothes. The TV only has one English Channel - BBC. While the bed itself is comfortable, the flat, Japanese pillows are not very comfortable. There is good, strong Internet. Coffee and Green Tea provided daily, as well as bottled water whenever your room is cleaned.

Staff very friendly and SPOKE ENGLISH!Great location, 1 minute walk to a metro station, not very well connected but from that line you can connect easily to other lines. Also walking distance from Shinjuku shops, bar and restaurants area. The room is very small but very clean and nice. Bed very confortable. There is a spa which is free and very good (a nude jacuzzi, separate men and women, a strange experience though).

Be ready for tiny rooms - luggage opening and moving around are tough! Bathroom is Japanese modular unit-also tiny! The room is a bit stuffy too. As a solo, it would be better. Given that we arrived before NYE, we paid a lot for the small space. :(Pro is the location-its 5-10 min walk to all the stations in Shinjuku. There is a great gyoza place right across for late night grub. Staff is friendly and helpful with tons of info. Would not stay again.

Located not far from JR Shinjuku station and situated on a rather quiet street. Check i in and check were a breeze. Rooms were tiny as expected since this is Tokyo, but they were well maintained and very clean. There was a system announcement in the morning in Japanese and it took several minutes for staff to address this over the PA system in English to assure guests that it was a false fire alarm. I think that could've been handled better.

It was very closed to the center and convenience for subway and metro line.The room very small no space enough for 2 bags but staff at the reception can speak English well The room was very clean and shiseido amenity goods i love shampoo and body bath and paper bird on bed when we arrived If I go to Tokyo alone again will stay here because its safe and easy for transportation

We were two people for 5 nights. The rooms are so small. There was just enough room to squeeze one bag at foot of bed. The rooms are very clean, the bed itself is comfortable. We had to ask the front desk for North American style pillows, as the ones provided in the rooms are more like flat head mats. (They do have big fluffy pillows available but they were hesitant to give them to us, which we found a bit frustrating.). The tub is tiny but the water pressure is good. There are coin laundry machines in the basement - 500 yen for a wash (it includes soap) and 100 yen for 30 minutes for dryer (we found we needed at least one hour for clothes to dry, just throw in 200 yen at once). Gyoemmae is sorta at the edge of Shinjuku, so it’s a bit quieter. There are lots of restaurants nearby, and it’s walkable ie 10 minutes to central Shinjuku. This hotel is right next to a metro stop.

The room is really very small, no space to leave the bags on the floor, bed also very small for 2 persons,The mattress was very good, the pillow unusual for us but ok, everything was clean, no lobby, not even a chair to sit and wait at the entrance (should be easy to do),At the good side is, there are some washing machines with dryers, a microwave, and a vending machine.

We stayed for one night, Two adults with two back packs and Two hand luggage bags, it was very small and cramped but fine for one night and very good value for money.The rooms are extremely clean.The pillows are not great and extremely thin.The shower sprays everywhere and floods the bathroom.No coffee, but they do give you loads of very thoughtful lovely extras. they provide tissues, razors, hairband, cotton buds, toothbrush set, shower cap.slippers and Japanese style bathrobe to use as well as having a hairdryer, a kettle and shampoo, conditioner and bodywash.very good value for money and very clean in a good location for transport to Narita and shops, restaurants and sight seeing.check-in staff are extremely kind and sweet and welcoming, also speak very good english.15 minute walk with heavy luggage to main shinjuku station to catch Narita express to the airport.would reccommend for good value for money, covenience Nd good location and a clean cosy room for the night.

This was our first stay at an APA hotel, and based on our experience, we'd gladly stay again (with some caveats). Located just 150 meters from the main entrance of the Shinjuku Gyoenmae station, and immediately across the street from the Shinjuku Gyoen park, the hotel is cozy, staff are efficient and friendly, and the bonus is having an onsite public bath AND coin laundry on the same floor (which we used since we were traveling with kids). The rooms are typical of Tokyo hotels: Tiny, but extremely clean and efficiently organised. We also enjoyed the breakfast spread (be careful, we had a bit of a misunderstanding with the breakfast vouchers) and the street is filled with local eateries and at least 3 convenience stores. The neighborhood isn't as seedy as some say, compared to Kabukicho, and it's pretty calm at night yet a short walk takes you to the heart of the Shinjuku madness. There's much to like, so much in fact we're considering to stay again in an APA property the next time we're in Tokyo.

Great location with metro line on your doorstep. Staff are friendly and really know what they are doing, handling and issue with ease. The room was very clean, warm and incredibly quiet for such a central location. An added bonus is the spa in the basement. My single room was small - it's Tokyo so that's a given, but was very well equipped with everything I might have needed. Great location, great price. Would definitely stay again.

Stayed here for about 9 night's, it's conviently located but the room was the smallest I've ever stayed in when traveling through Japan. When my room was cleaned it was unfortunately never cleaned properly, there was always something missed & I found it annoying that on day's I didn't need my room cleaned I would arrive to a plastic bag filled with towels & other item's I didn't need that would just end up taking up space in the room. Bed & pillows were comfortable & the bathroom was a decent size but the direction the shower sprays caused flooding as it would hit the top of the bathtub & then just flow onto the floor. There is no lobby/waiting area at this specific hotel so if you get picked up & taken to the airport like I do you'll have to go wait somewhere else & come back or in the worst case scenario if APA is fighting with the company picking you up they won't even allow that company on the premises so you'll need to lug all your heavy suitcases to another hotel to get picked up like I had to this trip. I was also expecting a fax of a confirmation from the pick up company but when I checked with reception they "hadn't recieved" anything but when I checked with the pick up company they faxed it to me on my 4th day here, so I speculate it was just thrown away as the 2 companies are fueding.

The pluses for this hotel are its location and its pleasant staff.On the minus side, the breakfasts were mediocre, the room minuscule and with a locked, non-transparent "window", and there was no means to control the temperature. I was alone in a double and felt cramped and claustrophobic, without even enough floor space to open my suitcase except directly outside the bathroom door.I was here on a business trip and was expecting a4 *Hotel, so perhaps if I had come with different expectations I wouldn't have been so dissatisfied with the little box I was provided with to sleep in...

Had a good 4 night stay.Yes the rooms are tiny. The bathrooms are minute. But being Japan, everything is incredibly functional and efficient and after a day you get used to it and make it work.The beds are super comfy (but BYO pillow!) - what they give you is maybe 5cm thick, and nard as a rock - I couldn’t believe it!The shower is very good, great pressure and temperature and they provide high quality towels changed daily. (They don’t change the bedding for the duration of your stay). There is an air conditioning unit in each room but you can’t control the temperature This is a major downside as the hotel decide on a central temperature and that’s what everyone is stuck with - you can turn the unit on or off but it will blow air at the temperature the hotel decides . It was WAY too hot for my stay, thankfully I had a room with a window that opened so I could cool the room that way. I couldn’t use the Onsen as I have tattoos but it seemed popular, and the basement level has an ice machine and laundry (700 yen to wash and dry) which was convenient and appreciated. The lifts can be frustrating as the hotel is so busy, it’s not uncommon to return to a full foyer of people waiting for the lift (that’s if you can fit between the 100s of cases stored in the lobby all day). Having said that it is so quiet in the rooms - however they have done the soundproofing works as you are rarely disturbed by noise from the lifts/corridor and can get a really good sleep.The staff were so helpful to me, especially with changing the huge value notes you get from the ATM in Japan into manageable smaller bills, and allowing me 2 hours late checkout for 2000 Yen which was a blessing given my flight at Narita wasn’t until 5pm. Although it would seem to be a business hotel it is overrun with Western tourists, suggesting correctly that it’s a great base to explore Tokyo - the location could hardly be better. Metro station close by or a 10 minute walk to the JR lines at Shinjuku.Overall a good stay, even with my misgivings about the pillows and the air-con I would stay here again as it was comfortable enough for the price, the location is excellent and the staff very pleasant and helpful.

So I picked this hotel for its fantastic location to the subway and other sites. It was a one night stay. Upon checking in (I was 1 hr early) I got told I needed to pay 1000 yen if I wanted my room now. I was sick and just wanted to crash so I paid. Upon getting to the room it’s incredibly hot and stuffy so I called and asked why the air conditioning wasn’t working and they said that the air conditioning is centralized which means guests can not control it in the room and that they controlled it. This was not disclosed to me upon checking in. I didn’t pursue the matter and I guess this was my fault because upon coming back from dinner the room was hot and stuffy and now they had turned on the heater because guess what it’s winter in Japan. Umm it’s 20C outside and I called them and here is where the lack of customer service or care comes into play. They don’t care all their other customers are cold and the ones that were hot are given fans so they have run out of fans too. I will just have to open my window to a very busy street and try and sleep. No solutions offered and no apology. So here I am in my stuffy room unable to sleep because they only care about your money and don’t really care what happens post your paying

It is hard to start this review.I stayed at APA Hotel in Gion/Kyoto last year and it was great, so I booked Tokyo with them this time.Location is great. Hotel is situated literally next door to the Subways station. There are infinite Restaurants within walking distance, many convenience stores, beautiful Park and Government Building nearby. About 20 minutes’ walk to famous Shinjuku Station and those little streets, everybody is so exciting about.BUT! I paid extra for the upper floor room with a view. Expected more than what I received.The room was spacious for Japanese standards, and very clean. Comfortable bed.The token kettle was there to make tea or coffee, but no cups, glasses or spoons on offer.I was supplied with two paper cups instead. Really?Also, they advertise the complementary cell phone, which is customary for most of hotels around the globe. Therefore, I did not organize International Roaming as I was expecting that phone to help me navigating my movements around.There was no phone.I asked the Concierge and they had no idea what I was talking about. I was offered the use of their Land Line … at the small charge. All I wanted was GPS! I pulled out my laptop and showed them their ad (Photo # 28 on their website) and they still had no idea what I was talking about.That takes me to another issue.The Reception People are supper polite and friendly, but their English skills are minimal.I do not want to sound patronizing as I am visiting the foreign country. Made an effort to learn basic language, but it is a busy international hotel and they should be able to communicate a bit better.It took four people and about 30 minutes to confirm my Airport Shuttle booking. Most of them just stood there, looking at me blankly when I showed them a document with the number to call.So, I am not dissing this Hotel, but would not stay there again.

Check in was a bit different put your details and pay in an atm type machine which gave you a ticket which you took to the desk and they processed it and gave you your room number. The hotel its self is very nice the rooms are small but nothing unusual in Japan and the beds are hard! The room was nice and clean albeit a bit cramped. Very good location a half hour walk from Shinjyuku Station and metres away from Gyoemmae Station. The road its on has good shopping and isotan across the road. The restaurant is very good lunch time is very busy with a lot of office people eating there. We had dinner there it was very nice and breakfast was very good lots of choices both Japanese and Western.

My second stay at a different APA hotel during this trip & was very satisfied. Location: 200 feet away from Shinjuku gyoenmae station (exit 1) on marunouchi line. 10 min walk to main Shinjuku station & Takashimaya Time Sq. Also close to Isetan & 0101 department stores. Lots of restaurants & 24 hr diners in the vicinity, highly recommend the Gyozanofukuho gyozas right across the street that opens late (until 4:30 am on weekdays?) Facilities: small rooms which is the norm in Tokyo, bed ok but mattress slightly tilted, pillows were thin & flat which was standard for all APA hotels & most westerners will find it uncomfy. We requested for extra pillows the first nite but they were out, 2nd day we asked again & 2 very fluffy pillows were delivered promptly. I was impressed by the complimentary spa facilities which had indoor pool and a smaller open air semi-outdoor pool, it was similar to the facilities at the APA hotel & resort Nishishinjuku gochome-eki tower albeit slightly smaller.Staff & service: very prompt & courteous, they also helped us filling out the forms & arranged for Black Cat luggage service which stored 2 of our luggage for 1 week ($3200 JPY only) while we traveled to other countries, then delivered the luggage to our next hotel when we returned. Overall we were very satisfied by our stay, impressed by their facilities, service & location, will def consider staying here again on our next Tokyo trip.

Staff were nice and friendly, room was probably the smallest hotel room I have ever stayed in, but it did the job. Breakfast was average. Unfortunately did not use the spa area. Location was excellent. Very close to two different stations, it was easy enough how to figure out where you wanted to go. Few things to consider. Chair or some type of seating area in the reception. A reception full of suit cases is not the most welcoming visual. Lots of self service check in machines that no one was using or were out of service, maybe use that space to store luggage? Lastly. CREATE A SMOKING AREA! It was extremely annoying having to find somewhere to smoke, as unless you had a smoking room, the hotel did not have a smoking area, due to the hotel being in a non smoking district.

Great hotel, walkable distance to Shinjuku. next to Mrt station. However, the exit to the hotel is all stairs. advise to walk from Shinjuku is better if you're carry a heavy luggage. opp the hotel sells the best gyoza should totally try it.

Small compact room but good value for such a central location. Close to restaurants and shops and various subway stops. Pleasant and helpful front-of house staff and despite my lack of knowledge of the Japanese language, communication was easy.

APA hotels are a little like Travelodge, stripped back a bit but offering all essentials. This hotel like so many in Tokyo had small but perfectly formed rooms, not much space for luggage and clothes storage. It did have a decent capsule bathroom, air conditioning wi fi etc and was reasonably quiet for a busy area. It has the park just at the rear and was a 15m walk to Shinjuku centre. Food was OK but opening times were strange. No seating whatsoever in reception and a limited laundry service although a launderette in the basement. Check in/out by machine a little strange and what we saw of limited staff indicated friendly and helpful

This is a centrally located hotel, part of the APA group, and it has 400+ extremely compact rooms which require some carefully coordinated living if there’s two of you. There’s basically no room for anything, so it’s really more of a place to sleep rather than stay. Brilliantly designed bathroom with everything in a minute space. Unfortunately the breakfast restaurant is very basic and the room cramped and messy Definitely not a pleasure to eat in, and strict enforcement of a 9.30 finish even on a very busy weekend.

We stayed for 5nights during our visit .As we were travelling to different places in Japan we left our big luggage at the hotel before returning to stay one night before our return to London.The hotel was very accommodating and staff (specially Ms Y.Shimzu) very helpful.The rooms although small provide all facilities .The hotel is very clean and breakfast provided is very nice providing good varieties .Staff try and resolve any issues and are very polite and calm. The Public baths on floor B1 is lovely . Great location with convenient access to Sinjuku Gyoemmae station and a 24 hour convenience store and nice choice of restaurants within walking distance.Will definitely stay on my return and recommend to new visitors .

Decent hotel that has a rare onsen in the basement! Rooms are small but practical. Unfortunately, it is close to a busy part of Tokyo and if you are light sleeper, the noise might be a rude awakening.

Stayed here for 7 nights. Be prepared. Room & bathroom are small. Try not to bring a big suitcase. The hotel provide shower, shampoo, toothpaste, toothbrush, etc . Walking distance to Nishin Shinjuku station. There a family and Lawson near the hotel as well. Is a convenient store, open 24 hours.

Chose this hotel essentially based on location and price.As the name suggest the hotel is located minutes from Shinjuku Gyoemmae Metro station and is within walking distance of Shinjuku station (Tokyo’s largest ) and Shinjuku samchome so you have plenty of options when deciding the best route for your daily expeditions It walking distance to Shinjuku shopping precinct, Tokyo’s infamous red light district, golden Gai the post war bar area , and the gay area of Tokyo.The hotel features a restaurant and and Osen spa but that pretty much it when it comes to amenities Rooms are small but functional very clean and comfortable And staff were helpful and pleasant We stayed in a double room which was essentially a queen size bed against a wall, room for a desk in the other wall with mini fridge and small bathroom with Japanese tub and shower over it This hotel is not luxury by any stretch but it’s exceptionally clean and beds are comfortable.They also allow early check in with a fee if rooms are available. Early checkin is not common in Japan even when rooms are available, The double room was a squeeze for a couple but fine if your sightseeing all day. We travelled with carryon luggage only if you have large luggage it’s going to be very tight Recommend for solo and light packing couples

checked into the hotel, clean and decent. the room is really small though, but with this price point, can't really complain too much. functional room, leaves little to manoeuvre when you have a large suitcase. the location is convenient, a little walk 10-15 mins gets you to Shinjuku. Shinjuku gyoen is right beside the hotel.

Good value for fantastic location amongst lots of great shops, eateries and bars in a very lively and central part of Tokyo. The hotel itself feels fairly new and is well presented, super clean and quite comfortable with all the basics you expect in a budget hotel. Rooms are super small but very clean and well maintained and nicely designed so I don't mind sacrificing the size considering the great location and cleanliness. Rooms are quite peaceful and quiet. Beds and linen very comfortable but could have had better pillows. Bathroom tiny but well designed. Nice little onsen in the basement is a bonus. Front desk services and lobby are very basic but it does have full service laundry plus self serve laundry. They also offer luggage storage. Only thing I dislike is sometimes there's a long wait for the lifts.Overall I think you get good value for such a great location with small but clean and very comfortable rooms.

I guess for Japan standards this is a fair sized room with frosted window (thus no view). There’s a desk and room to put your luggage beside the bed. Enough room to do push-ups since there’s no gym. They have bidet toilets so you can wash your booty after you’ve done your business. There’s a breakfast option but there’s many ramen, yakitori or izakaya options in the area. Away from the bustling area of Shinjuku but about a 15 mins walk away. If you want to take the MTR, it’s two stops. Convenient enough but also quiet. Service at front desk speaks English and Mandarin as well. If they have a mifi to borrow, it would make this hotel a five star rating.

I have to say my first impressions were dreadful. You arrive disheveled and tired and there isnt even a chair to sit on in the whole of the reception area. The rooms might be available but you can only go to them if you pay an extra 1,000 yen per hour extra. It rather reminds me of a budget airline where you are considered purely as a credit card and not a customer. So different to our next hotel The Knot which was so stylish, cheaper, larger with more comfortable rooms, and let you into your room earlier without paying extra. At this hotel I was forced to sit on the floor as there was nowhere to sit. So unprofessional to have guests sitting on the floor. So there you are finally arrived at your hotel, nowhere to sit you are literally turfed out of the hotel until 1500 when everyone crowds back in to get into their extremely tiny rooms. Luckily close by are the national gardens so we went there and laid on the bench for a couple of hours. Beds I have to admit are comfortable, how the staff actually get in to clean the rooms remains a mystery. We did get used to the room after a few days and would have assumed all hotels in Tokyo are like this had we not stayed next in the Knot. Maybe its not as close to Shinjuku station as this one, but its miles ahead in customer care. I will certainly not stay here on my next trip to Tokyo when there is so much better out there.

- Three elevators - 20 min wait to go down 5 floors- Breakfast posted from 6:30 AM to 9:30 AM. We arrived at 8:30 am and there was no food left and actually no place to sit anyway. - Rooms are typically tiny but even by Japanese standards these are like being in a closet. Double room is really for one person. If your two to a room one person must be laying on the bed so the other can move around. - Public Japanese bath was beautiful, but full of culturally ignorant tourists who ignored traditional way of bathing and treated a sacred custom like it was the local kiddie swimming pool.  Bottom line - you get what you pay for. APA lures you in with lower prices. Then like some airlines heard’s you in like cattle in a barn. Japan has some of cleanest, most beautiful hotels in the world, with service second to none. APA chain is not one of them.

We enjoyed our 1 night stay at this hotel for our last evening in Tokyo. I have seen some reviews mentioning small and sub par rooms....I dont know where else these people have stayed in Tokyo, but each place we stayed in had very small rooms. That is simply the way it is done here. Our hotel before this one did not even have enough room for us to open our luggage and walk around the room at the same time.So yes, the room is small. However, check-in was smooth and easy, they allow you to drop your luggage off early and the staff were very polite and kind. There is a restaurant on site if you do not want to travel far and the place was very clean. (There is also a small Michelin Rated restaurant right out the back door and around the corner. People were lined up down the street for it.)The amenities in the room were good, the shower was more spacious than some of the other places we stayed in our time here, and the water pressure was also good. It was a nice cozy stay.Check-out was smooth. You drop your cards in a machine that time stamps them and checks you out. This technology was quite interesting, and easy to use. The location was not amazing and we found there were not many decently rated restaurants in the area,(outside of the Michelin restaurant that was lined ulntoonlong for us),however we did not mind the short subway ride.To get back to Haneda airport we took the Marunouchi Line just a short 3 minute walk from the hotel and then caught another subway to the Monorail. It was fairly simple. We would recommend this hotel, especially for someone wanting to visit both Shinjuku and Shibuya. It was right in between both.

My wife and I stayed at the Apa Shinjuku Goemmae for 3 nights. The staff were polite, friendly and professional. However our floor (11th) and our room had a bad odour. It was moist, humid and almost urine like. It was unbearable so we had the A/C blasted and which was freezing at night with our blankets. It was either the urine smell or freeze, we chose to freeze. The front desk was able to find us a new room for the last night and we were planning to move but we got back late that evening, was checking out 6am the next day and it was too much hassle to repack our belongings so we decided not to.

Stayed in this hotel for 4 nights, it has everything you need and more. Very clean and well serviced, friendly staff. The location is wonderful metro station and bus stop nearby (1min walk if that) only a few train stops from city centre.We loved the cheap coin operated washing machine and dryer so handy! Family mart, Lawson and nice restaurants walking distance.The rooms are small but nothing different to Japan's standards for hotel rooms. Would stay here again!

Me and my partner stayed here for 4 nights and it was perfect for us! This is a very very tiny room. Almost not enough room to move around with our luggages in there, but I think all the hotels around this area are this way. But we had everything we needed, a desk, a tv, a queen bed, a fridge.. the bathroom was immaculate, and it comes with hairties, hair dryer, brush, comb, even a scrubber! And it was so clean and they clean the room everyday and refill everything! (esp the free bottle of water they leave in your room!) The staff speaks english and always friendly and they have 24 hr service! They even have free umbrellas for you to borrow if you need it. They also have a laundry area and a gym and spa.For the price and location, I think this hotel is great! It's about an 8 min walk to Shinigawa station and you are staying minutes away from stores like Uniqlo and LV and the 5th Ave of Tokyo! Lots of food places around as well and 7-11!!

My group of 4 stayed for 2 nights in end-August (one double, one twin). The rooms are very small, and decorated in dark colours, which doesn't help. The room was clean and beds were comfortable but narrow. There is a small window. Location-wise, it was decent. It's a bit too far from Shinjuku (15ish minutes, worse with luggage) and Shinjuku-sanchome station is about 5-10 minutes away. It definitely isn't in the centre of things, but it's decent, and as a trade-off the area is quiet. Plenty of convenience stores/supermarkets close by. Overall, I think it was good value for the double, but not the twin (which was nearly 2.5x the price, for some reason). I would probably pay a little more and stay somewhere with a bigger room / better location.

My cousin and I stayed here for three nights. I would definetely recommend APA Gyoen-mae to others. It's located in a more quiet area but close to both nice restaurants and the metro. APA truly masters "kaizen" - even though the rooms are tiny they can fit everything in there and you still have the feeling of staying a very nice and sort of spacious place. APA Gyoen-mae also has their own sento which we did use a couple of times - so nice!! There's a restaurant connected to the hotel, we didn't use it however.

The is located on quite location which not clowned as Shinjuku and I prefer that. Hotel staff is so-so service and some of them not good to Speak English but it is very simple on Japan. Amenities were very good and high quality. Recommend this hotel for Shinjuku

I enjoyed my stay at this hotel! The location was great, not too far from the large Shinjuku station and super close to the smaller Gyoenmae subway station. With a 5-10 minute walking distance to restaurants and shopping in Kabukicho, it's close enough to the action, but far enough away to get a little peace and quiet from all the noise. The hotel itself was clean, modern, and very comfortable. Pillows were a little strange (kind of hard and flat), but I travel with my own small personal pillow so it was no big deal. The bed was very comfortable and although the room and bathroom were quite small (and I'm only 5'4"/163 cm tall and was bumping my knees and arms on the walls of the bathroom), this is just the norm all around Japan unless you pay a huge amount of money for a super luxury hotel. The staff was very friendly and helpful with all of my questions! If I were visiting the Shinjuku area again, I'd stay at this hotel.

We stayed here for 2 nights. The hotel is about 10 minutes from Shinjuku station where you can book your Shinkansen tickets for days ahead if you forgot to do this at the airport or didn't have time. The hotel itself is very clean and the on site Onsen was a welcome start to the morning. The breakfast was a delight with choices for most tastes. High end shopping is close by if that is your thing.

The APA hotel chain is reasonably priced (but not cheap) and rooms are small but normal by Japanese standards. Laundry facilities at the hotel were in high demand but very useful. The pool is on the terrace - it’s only 1m deep at all ends and costs 1000¥ to use so isn’t really worth it.On the whole a good hotel and suites our needs.

If I could give it less stars I would, staff disinterested to the point of rude. Asked to speak to the manager still waiting. Booked a disabled non smoking room. Room/broom cupboard that I was given to start with was a smoking room/broom cupboard is so small that can’t even turn the chair. Frosted glass window so don’t even know if I have a view or not.

This is a great choice and a great value in Shinjuku. I have previously stayed at Tokyo Prince, Hyatt Regency and Hilton Tokyo all close by - I prefer this hotel let me explain why. I am a US traveller with the average amount of luggage (too much). Room size was just fine for a solo traveller or as others have pointed out two people who get along very well. I had more then enough room for luggage, no problemI was torn between this hotel and the APA in Kabukicho, this one is a nice quiet neighborhood with zero outside noise, I slept quite well even for afternoon naps. No street noise. Its an excellent value for the $, yen, or euro, excellent valueWifi very fast and reliable. Aircon works great. Its humid in Tokyo today but 19C in my room. I have a small fridge they provide bottles of water and of course from the Family Mart across the street you can get any drinks you want.Bed has been very comfortable with daily maid service to clean. Lastly when I stayed at Hilton or Hyatt when you walk outside you are in an area a bit separate from Tokyo. Not so here, when you walk out the front door you are immersed in Tokyo and very close to Metro stop. If you are looking for a Tokyo experience then this is much preferred to the US hotels. I will for sure stay again.

Best features first: location near National garden; proximity to subway; excellent room service (happy to provide more pillows, more coffee, generous bathroom necessities, very clean); nice Onsen in basement; variety of convenience stores and good quick eats within a block.On the down side, the rooms are very small; the big bed was great but floor space tiny (for 2, take turns in getting dressed); a bit claustrophobic and there’s no general seating area anywhere including reception - if you want to get out of the room for a while go to the national garden. The in house restaurant breakfast choices are ok but dinner menu an unsuccessful mix of cuisines and expensive for what is offered.Before we arrived for our first visit to Tokyo the hotel could not advise how to get there from Narita airport. This is how: go to the JR information point at the airport. Get a ticket for the Narita express (the N’ex express) to Tokyo central; there, get a subway map and find the Maranouchi line, take it and get off at M10. You will need some local currency, available at the airport. Subway tickets are dispensed from machines; choose your language and follow instructions.Once you’ve figured out the amazingly well run train system you will have no problem getting around economically. For instance, a guided tour to Mt Fuji for 2 will cost over 35,000 yen; if you take the Mt Fuji express to Kawaguchiko (one stop past Mt Fuji and best viewing, book a return ticket a few days before at a JR info point or on line) include the cruise on the lake, for less than 20,000 yen total.

The room we got was small comparing with the European standards but bigger than on other same range hotels in Tokyo. The room was clean and with all the equipment's in good state of functioning. Around 15 min to walk to/from the main Shinjuku station. The breakfast could be better, but is ok offering options not only for locals but also for Europeans. Good free wifi in the room. Plenty of choices to have the dinner in the close area.Tip: For those travelers who intent to visit more cities/places in Japan do not forget to buy from home a JR pass. It is very helpful in Tokyo and all Japan and can save a lot of money instead buying tickets at every movement by train/metro

Great location - just a block away from Tons of food, bars and the metro. Check in was easy and they held our bags until we came back. Front staff spoke decent English and helped us during the process. Cost 1,000 yen to check in at noon instead of 3pm. Pillows were very disappointing. Room was small and bed was soft. Did it’s job as a place to crash after a busy day sight seeing. Check out was easy and only required us to put our ticket in a reader. Overall good experience.

APA is located close to many great attractions and the subway. There is a 100Yen store, 7-11 and fresh fruit/veggie shop nearby which will become your "go to" places. It is a walk away from the amazing National Garden and MANY places to shop and eat. The rooms are small but clean. Even if you put a don't clean room sigh up they will still leave daily towels and essentials outside your door. There are washing machines and dryers in the basement. They have a money changer in the lobby. The spa is in the basement and if you are not shy, it is a clothing optional. The staff is kind and will help as much as they can. Taxis stop right outside - ask the staff to write on a slip of paper in Japanse where you are going, it helps. Learn some Japanese such as thank you and hello. It is costly in Japan but with a little research, you can save your pennies to spend on trips outside of the city.

I booked a room here last year after extensive research and was really pleased with it. Yes, it's small, but the rooms are well designed with plenty of facilities. We spent two weeks in the hotel and it was intimate, but perfectly comfortable for a couple. There is a lack of floor space, but we could easily get to our bits and bobs by popping our suitcases on the bed each day so we could open them up properly.The location can't be beat- it's in central Shinjuku, but in a peaceful area close to a beautiful park (which is well worth a visit). There are lots of restaurants and bars around and the hotel also has a restaurant on-site. The train station is a mere 10 minute walk away so it's easy to get around Tokyo. I really appreciated coming back to such a comfortable hotel after a long day sight-seeing.We arrived early and jet lagged, but the staff were happy to look after our bags whilst our room was being prepared which made things a lot easier. Check in was a bit weird as we were supposed to do it on a machine, but it wasn't working so Reception ended up checking us in the old fashioned way. As you would expect from Japan, you have a fancy toilet with a bidet and the rooms are cleaned to a high standard.I can't comment on breakfast and the onsen as we didn't use those facilities (sadly I have a couple of small tattoos and like most onsens in Japan, people with tattoos are banned from using it). The photos certainly looks super cool though, and if I wasn't so bashful I imagine I'd have been a lot more disappointed that I'd missed out.There's a vending machine in the basement which sells cans of beer and shochu as well as soft drinks. A nice little convenience for when you don't want to pop out to a shop, and a great way of using up your loose change!

This hotel was a great choice for our plans in the Shinjuku district. The breakfast choices were ok - nothing special.The room was very small - just enough room for the double bed and not much else. If you’re sharing a room with someone be sure that you get on with each other as the lack of space is a challenge - but perhaps the norm in Tokyo mid budget hotels? The hotel had a really nice complementary Onsen which was a nice surprise.

1. Location: very near to Tokyo Metro (via the Marinouchi Line — which is also easily connected to the Narita Express). Easily a 5-10 min to Shinjuku Park (where we managed to see the Sakura blossoms), Shinjuku SanChoMe (for the restaurants and bars).2. Checkin counter: very friendly staff. They have a different way of check-in process. They’d get your passport details first, confirm your booking, give you the hotel card key, then they’d direct you to a sort of self-registration kiosk machine (where you’d slot in your hotel card key, pay via debit or credit card, then get the receipt — where your room number is indicated). Make sure you know your credit card pin and your magnetic stripe is activated!3. Rooms: super small. Just enough space for luggage. No shelves, they have hangers by the wall. Soft bed. TV has local channels, and one BBC channel (certain times have Japanese dubbed in them). Small fridge for your drinks. Has hairdryer. Mirror too.4. Toilet: decent size. Water closet has the washer! Shower is great too. Fresh towels everyday.Overall, I’d go back to this place again! :)

Other than the decent location near Shinjuku, there's nothing special about this property. Poor breakfast, staff seemed confused to answer basic questions about WIFI, iron etc...Got a smoking room with terrible smell, AC didn't work. This should be a $25/night hotel not 180

if you plan to spend most of the time outside shopping/travelling, this is a cheap alternative since you just want to store your stuff and a place to sleep. Good Short walk to SHinjuku shopping areas. Surrounded by convenience stores ( a few of them!) and near to train station. BadIts not near to the main JR line. Room is very small. limited space for huge luggage and there's no wardrobe. Toilet is pathetic.

I like this hotel because its location, just 2 stops from Shinjuku Station. The staff at this hotel speaks English and are very helpful. The breakfast buffet is great with both Japanese and western selection, and you can even order omelette to your likings. As usual the room is very small, this time we got a room very near the elevator so not even a closet in this one, you have to creative when managing your suite cases. We asked for extra pillows and got it!

This hotel is close to transits for getting around Tokyo. There is also a ton of shops, restaurants, and activities in walking distance (parks, museums etc.). The rooms are small, but clean. The soaking tubs were great after a long day!

OVERALL: Highly metro accessible hotel catering to budget conscious tourist and business men. Located in good eating and shopping, Shinjuku. Less than a block away from National Gardens. +’s:@ Clean and efficient space: If you expect a large US room, rescale to Japanese measures. The rooms are solid and tight but that is what you get for the price point and location. @ Friendly Staff@ Lots of free toiletries@ Japanese baths downstairs: Did not get a chance but like the option -‘s@ Japanese size rooms (see pluses for my comment)

The location is the only good thing going for this hotel. The rooms are very small and do not reflect the price you are asked to pay. The staff are friendly but you find that across all of Japan. The bed was small and being 187cm tall my legs were hanging out the end of the bed. The pillows were nothing like we have ever experienced before and were only about 75mm thick. We asked for an extra pillow but were told that they had no spare pillows. Really a hotel of this size and the price they charge had no spare pillows. What if there were an accident in a room. We asked for a blanket and were again told it could not be done as they had used their daily allowance already. Overall I think there are better accomodation options in this area. Would not recommend and would not stay again.

Great location, located on the edge on Shinjuku. Very clean and quiet, rooms are quite small but comfortable. Breakfast is nice and staff are helpful. Slightly pricy for what you get regarding room size etc. close to restaurants and about a 8min walk from the metro train. Overall enjoyable.

We stayed there 3 nights as second choice as our favourite hotel was full. The first night was a nightmare in a tiny 'smoking' room where one could hardly breathe because the carpet and cloth-lined walls were impregnated with the smell of old cigarettes, quite disgusting for non-smokers. The overall sense of disgust was made worse by large cigarette-burn holes in the only chair in the room.Fortunately we were given another room for the remaining nights which was far better - on 12th floor with a lovely view of Shinjuku, slightly bigger and over all fresher, so we enjoyed the stay.Good location, next to a lovely park, very good place from which to wonder around Tokyo, huge number of excellent restaurants for all tastes/budgets in the vicinity. Not cheap but worth the price.

Staff are very nice and make check in very quick and easy. Location of hotel is great and very central to train line and the busy streets of Shinjuku! Only negative is the rooms are so tiny, hardly any room for two suitcases to be open.

Convenient, clean . Good breakfast.Best tip previously gleaned from trip advisor. Bring your own pillow! Worth it. Small room, but manageable.Book in advance, it’s much cheaper .Interesting walks through park down the road. Convenient for station.

A quieter area of Shinjuku but still only five minutes from the main town areas. This was the second APA hotel we stayed in. The rooms are small but clean, the room was very quiet, the breakfast is good value for the 800Yen per person. The reception area is automatic but is also staffed by three receptionists who although did not speak English very well were nice and tried there hardest to help which means a lot.

Tokyo isn’t really about staying in your room. There is so much to do each day is likely a 12/13hr day exploring. You want somewhere nice and clean to come back to and that is well located. This hotel is all those things. The room we had is very small. It’s a standard double. I understand most hotel rooms are like that. The location is perfect though. Located so well in Shinjuku and near a sub station. Perfect place to stay

This is a good choice to be fairly close to Shinjuku Station. It is very close to the metro. The hotel is quite large and very busy and business like. Check in and check out times are fiercely adhered to. I wish I had time to visit the spa, maybe next time.
