ViaeWarrior
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Situated in a more slow paced and quiet part of Shinjuku, the hotel was not too close, yet not too far from the center - with a one minute walk to the Shinjuku Gyoemmae metro or about 10 minutes walk to Shinjuku's main station, this was one of the things that we loved. There is also the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden within a few minutes walk - sadly we didn't have enough time to check it out. The room has everything you need and the staff are so friendly. Make sure to check out the hotel's onsen that they have onsite. :)Unfortunately for me, I have a rather high temperature body and always craving for the cold. It was surprising to find out that there was an air-con system, but was it was controlled by the hotel only - so I could not change it to how I wanted the temperature to be. Luckily there was a window that could be opened with about a 10cm gap, which allowed me to survive that nights that we were there.

i search the most favourable location in shinjuku and find this fab hotel. everything is nice and perfect. near station, near combini and their staff really friendly and helpful. I recommend this hotel for value of money and place to relax

One minute walk from Shinjuku Gyoemmae metro station, or a ten minute walk from Shinjuku main train station. . Layout of room was maximized to full potential given its small size. . Very big TV for a such a small room. Breakfast wasn't included but well worth the money and fantastic coffee.

Probably the smallest hotel room I've stayed. However, its strategic location & room amneties/cleanliness makes up for it. 24-hours convenience stores and subway station a stone's throw away.For Muslim travellers, there's a halal restaurant called Ramen Ouka which is within walking distance (advisable to make prior reservations).

This was my time staying at the APA Hotel Shinjuku. I’ve stayed in many hotels across Japan and this hotel rates very highly in the mid range.I elected to stay in the smallest room possible to save money - 11m square - so I will not write anything negative about the room size. That said, for those people looking at staying in the smallest room, even though it had a queen bed, I honestly think that a room this size is adequate only for one person, not two - there is barely floor space for one suitcase, let alone two. The stats, then:Good:. Excellent location, right next to the best park in Tokyo. A five minute walk to the hubbub of Shinjuku itself, so when you walk out the front door you are not trampled by thousands of people.. Also, easy to find on foot when stepping off the train - either a one minute walk from Shinjuku Gyoemmae metro station, or a ten minute walk from Shinjuku main train station.. Layout of room was maximised to full potential given its small size.. Very big tv for a such a small room.. Modern, compact bathroom, finished to a very high standard. This also included heated wall mirror to counteract condensation after showering - I love this feature.. Very pleasant restaurant ambience with excellent breakfast options - plenty to fill yourself up with before heading off for a day out in the city.Not so good:. Wifi is spotty.. Pillows were very insubstantial - may be a Japanese thing - pillows were not big and puffy as a Westerner like myself would expect.Would I stay here again?:. Absolutely. But I’d go for a bigger room.:)

On main road near train station. Many eateries nearby.. department store shopping is walking distance. Small room which is a regular sized room in Tokyo. Added extra of the hotel is Japanese hot bath in the lower floor.

The APA Hotel Shinjuku Gyoemmae offers visitors an excellent location near a major city attraction. The rooms are clean, efficient and just right. Tokyo is not a city you spend time lounging in your room, but rather you are out and about taking in everything.

It is my third time to stay at this hotel, and although it has tiny rooms, it has very good value for money. It is clean, safe and has all the basics i.e. hot shower, etc. until now when I am so disappointed with the free wifi that came with the package. It is intermittently working, and actually most of the time useless or painfully superslow. I told front desk about it, but the lady just shrugged? I also reported about the biddet not working, but noone came to fix until I found out myseld that the power button was off. How would a guest know where these power buttons are hidden?I am considering looking for other options in my next visit as wifi is non negotiable for me. Pity.

A few munites walk from Shinjuku Gyoen subway station (please aware this station does not have elevator/escalator). Convinient to Narita if you take taxi to Bus Tarminal Shinjuku, then Limousine bus to Narita.WIFI is too slow and could not access most web services, including Gmail, not to mention Facebook. The only the timeslot I can use WIFI was 3-4pm. Wired LAN did not work first, so I asked to change the room.They have fitted sheet and duvay, but no flat sheet. So I felt a bit chilly on my toe -- I am just 165 cm tool. The room size is Tokyo business hotel standard. i.e. you can barely put your suitecase in the space. The room was clear. They put books in all rooms written by the hotel owner... you can guess that kind of corporate mind.

This hotel is in a quieter part of Shinjuku, with a short walk to shops and the station. There are plenty of convenience stores and food options around, as well as the nightlife precinct within walking distance. This was our introduction to Tokyo, and couldn't have been better chosen - the rooms, while understandably small, were well set out, and had everything we needed, and the people around were lovely.

APA Hotel Shinjuku Gyoen mae is a one of the most affordable full service hotel options you can find in the Shinjuku area - its single rooms are small but well maintained, and there's even an onsen at the basement. The hotel breakfast was simple, and competently provided western and Japanese selections to start our mornings. APA has more than one hotel in Shinjuku, but Gyoen-mae has the advantage of being far away enough from the hustle and bustle to be peaceful, but close enough to Kabukicho if you want to explore some nightlife.APA is also right across from a climbing gym, if your schedule allows for some exercise.

The room is very small, but it is clean and has everything you need. The location is pretty close to everything including subway station. The park behind the hotel is beautiful. The bonus is the Onsen, even it is man made, you can soak your tired body from all the walking around in Tokyo. Staff is friendly.

Four things bothered me:1. The majority of the staff do not speak or comprehend basic English, for example "is there a message for me". I know this is a problem in all Japan. However this hotel was the last of 12 I stayed at, and none of the others were like that. I stayed there a whole week; at some point I just gave up...2. The wifi signal (actually all 3 of them in different parts of the building) is weak and keeps disconnecting.3. Two insulting interactions with the same "night manager" at the reception; the only rude person I've encountered in a month-long visit to Japan. When I complained to the manager, he responded with platitudes.4. An accumulation of small things.

My first trip to Japan. I chose to stay in a hotel instead of a hostel or capsule hotel. From the check-in, to the stay, the breakfast the whole experience was smooth and perfect. English communication is no problem. Just remember to speak slow and clearly. Instruction leaflets in English are available in the room. Remember the rooms in Tokyo hotels are tiny. The bed was super comfortable. The bathroom was fully equipped. The breakfast was sumptuous. Thank you for creating a comfortable space to return to after a long day.

i stay for 5 night in here .. the location is great. near to metro station and only take 1km or 15 min to JR station.. 15 min won't feel to long since there are many place that u can see..the room is big enough for 2 persons.. but i only hope that someday they can renovate the lobby.. maybe add some sofa or waiting place if u go in Group.. overall..its nice hotel.. u got what u pay for.. =)

I visit Tokyo 1-2 times per year and always stay in the Shinjuku Gyoenmae area as it is literally a 2 minute walk to gay nightlife. Yes the price is higher here than other areas, but any kind of taxi to another area home at late night will cost a lot and take away any savings you have.Usually I stay in AirBnBs but the law changed, so APA was my main choice. There are excellent places right nearby for quick food - cheap yakitori chain, AMAZING GYOZA right across the street, simple izakaya, cheap curry all with English menus if you need it. You can take Maronouchi subway line to Ginza, Tokyo Station, Haneda Airport (simple transfer). Much cheaper and simpler than going back and forth to giant Shinjuku Station.The bed was super comfortable. Rooms are tiny but it’s Japan so not much you can do about that. The pillows are kind of a joke - these super thin paper like things. Ask for extra. That’s my only “negative.”Staff stored bags properly on last day and check in/check out was easy with machines. Can even add one hour check out for 1,000Y aka 10 USD if you want.Will continue to stay here when I go back! Perfect location to explore and at night rest your head. Not somewhere to stay and luxuriate all day though haha.

Firstly this place is very clean and sterile. Cant fault it. How ever the photos on the hotel booking websites do NOT justify the size of the rooms and bathrooms. To put it in perspective I am a 6'3 male. I had to duck to get into the bathroom. The bed was so tiny and shoved against the wall. So not even my feet could hang over the edge (it hits the wall the bed) You can't open your suitcase and leave it open on the little suitcase stand they provide. There literally is NO room. So I found opening the suitcase every time to get clothes out and then having to stand it up right. I knew the room was going to be tiny but not this tiny. Anyone of my size should consider a different hotel. A major turnoff was the Air Conditioning system. Each level is controlled by front desk. So if everyone is cold the heating will be on. If everyone is hot, the cooling will be turned on.So uncomfortable some nights when you feel very warm and stuffy and you cant have the AC on cool cause the floor you're on pick the heating.I asked for a twin share room and they said they dont exist only the double bed.Which I found odd when its advertised here.The breakfast is delicious. Onsen hot spa downstairs is beautiful.

Around 9-12minutes walk from Shibuya Station if you are taking the JR line. Close to couple of subways (tokyo metro line). Rooms are clean but small but I guess this is usual in Tokyo. A lot of cafes, restaurants and grocery stores. Very convenient. The public bath is quiet and clean. Fantastic place to relax after a long day.Overall will come back if I’m back in Tokyo again.

Everithing was perfect but the space of the room was like the space in a camping van or worst. There was no space for our luggage nor the safety box, there was not a wardrobe naither. Throught the window in the afternoon enter a strong smell of fried fish. The breakfast was good, the cleaness as well, it is near at a metro station ect ect but , for me they missed the most important things.

We stayed here four nights. The rooms small but clean. The staff very helpful and well speaking English. We used the spa. The spa very clean. The location not far away from the Shinjuku, also the train station and bus terminal . Walking time from hotel around 10 to 15 minutes. Inside the bus terminal a Tokyo tourist information center. Here you can also store your luggage for a small amount. The different to other storage boxes is you can take it without you have to buy the fee again. Behind the hotel is the Shinjuku gyoen national garden. Around the hotel are shops like family mart, seven eleven, pharmacy and a lot restaurants. We didn’t take breakfast because we eat our breakfast outside .We like to come again, we felt in this hotel safe und happy.

I chose this hotel on the suggestion of what many others said about the hotel and it stands: It is a great budget hotel located near many tourist location, near the main JR station which is impt for movement when you have a JR pass. It still comes with onsen and Laundry services. Only complaint is the room is indeed really small, and hard to move around. It will be a challenge if you have more than 2 lugguage in a room for two. Otherwise, it is wallet friendly and a good place to crash!

APA Hotel Shinjuku Gyoemmae, was picked solely for it's location. Having stayed at other APA properties, which all had a similar feel, I had an idea of what to expect before arrival. By this I mean that it is a budget property. This isn't the place for you if you want to spend hours in your room relaxing/lounging...there is absolutely no space for this. However if you are just looking for a place to crash at night in a great location, it is worthy of consideration.  The room and bathroom are both VERY small, which at times can lead to a comedy of errors if two adults are both trying to maneuver around with luggage! It is however clean and decently appointed. The bed is comfortable, though the standard APA paper thin pillows make another appearance. The property has a restaurant on site, which appeared busy most nights. As VIP+ Expedia Members we were given a free drink our first night, but never actually dined there.  What makes this hotel most worthy of consideration is the location in Shinjuku, close to transit, as well as walking distance from MANY shops, restaurants, Golden Gai and Kabukicho. There is also several convenience stores and a grocery store nearby.

We enjoyed our stay (a couple in a double room - one bed). Here are some details:Location: Very good. Close to restaurants and 4 convenience stores (this is important when travelling in Japan!). Shinjuku station is about a 10 min walk and you can get anywhere in Tokyo from this main hub but there is a closer metro station as well. Right beside the beautiful Shinjuku National Garden. Quiet area close to all the action of Shinjuku.Check-in/out - was very easy but it was not busy when we arrived or left. Friendly staff. Room - small but fine for us. The only issue was the height of the bathroom ceiling. I am 5'10 and I could hit my head on the light fixture. My husband is 6'2 and he just fit in the shower. I think if you are taller it would be uncomfortable. But the shower head is hand held with good pressure so no problems there. We were also travelling with small suitcases. If you have alot of large luggage the room might feel smaller. 2 very flat pillows were provided but we just asked for more at the desk and it was no problem. Spa - free spa included. My husband used it twice and it was nice. The reception warned us about busy times so he just avoided those times.Laundry - 2 small coin washers and dryers are available. Soap is in the washer and included in the price. Was 100 yen for washer.

Decent location. A bit of a walk to the fun parts of town like the Golden Gai area. But the train station entrance is just at the end of the block. No seating in the lobby at all due to the small size.

I really liked this place. Other reviews refer to rooms being small, and they are no smaller than rooms you get in central Rome Paris etc. Hotel is spotless. The bonus for me was the japanese bath downstairs (free) and laundry with dryers. Hotel located in heart of tokyo just a few doors down from shinjuku gyonaemae metro (gate 1 i think) and walking distance to shinjuku. Plenty of restuarants and bars nearby. Friendly staff. All together top class.

OK, I'm new to Tokyo and not sure what is normal. We stayed at APA Hotel Shinjuku Gyoemmae and found the room (economy double) to be small like a hotel room in Amsterdam! The price was pretty good and we were a couple of blocks from the nearest subway. Check-in time was at 3 PM and although the room may have been ready sooner, we had to wait to three. The room and bathroom were very clean. The closet consisted of two hooks on the wall. I might look for a hotel with larger rooms if I go back to Tokyo. Staff was friendly and helpful.

Very nice hotel, clean and comfortable. The staff are very helpful and nice. The rooms are small (very small) which is the usual for a hotel of this price in Tokyo. The room was quite warm at night which was a little bit annoying but they had good air-con. The onsen/sauna was lovely and big. Overall a good stay and good value for the money on a great location when visiting Tokyo

This hotel is decently located within walking distance (10-15 minutes dragging luggage) from Shinjuku's manic main train station and even closer to two Metro stations. The area is great, close to grocery stores and about a million bars and restaurants! It's also just a few minutes walk to Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden – one of the highlights of Tokyo for me.The hotel itself is ok. My room was very small and somewhat dysfunctional. It's not terribly well designed with a huge television taking up half of the desk space in the room (could the television not be mounted on the wall?), poorly located power sockets and a bathroom designed so that one water faucet provides water for both the shower and sink. The two water pressure options were too high or two low. And the shower spewed water across the bath unavoidably onto the floor. The hotel lifts provided further frustration with some long waits and services stopping at virtually every floor from the tenth down! However, even with all that in mind, I would recommend this hotel as a decent option for a few days in Tokyo, especially for solo travellers.Breakfast in the restaurant was good with plenty of varied options covering all tastes. If you don't like the weak coffee, I found the 100 yen (67p GBP) take-out coffee from the nearby 7-Eleven to be great.

Great location. Walking distant to transit and restaurants. Close enough to the heart of Shinjuku, but far enough away that there aren't huge crowds.I've stayed here for several weeks at a time. The rooms are small, but that is normal for Japanese hotels. The rooms are well appointed and have everything you could possibly need.

I went in expecting the room to be small, but it was tiny. Would recommend 1 person per room or very small bags. Other than that the hotel was clean (non-smoking room) and was in a great location. Two subway stops within walking distance as well as Shinjuku station.Loved coming back to a crisp yukata to put on.Would stay here again next time I visit Shinjuku

I ve been to Tokyo for My honey Moon the room i slept in was very small and did smell of cigarettes. I asked to Change that cause i didnt ask for smoking room but they didn t understand nothin. So i was very upset..

I ended up here after an Airbnb debacle. It's not normally the kind of place I'd choose. However, once I'd accepted that I was staying there it was surprisingly OK. My room was so small I couldn't open my suitcase without putting it on my bed. The room was like a little cave. Despite it's size there was a 42 inch TV dominating the space. I wish it wasn't there. I got used to the size eventually and I felt safe and cozy in there. Although I didn't let the cleaning lady in because it was too hard for me to keep it neat enough to let her in. (I know I can't be the only person who cleans up before the cleaning lady comes through each day.)The bed was too soft and the pillows were flat and had old pillowcases on them. All the beddings felt a bit yucky, so if I stayed again I'd bring a little sleeping bag.I never really worked out the very complicated tap system in the bathroom. I didn't use the onsen because I have small tattoos but lots of people did as there were lots of half naked people in the elevators. They provide you with chambray kiminos and faux leather slides. I really like the slides am wearing them right now. I took the other pair from the room so will probably keep wearing this look for awhile. The staff weren't very friendly or helpful. The check in was automated on a touch screen and you toss your hotel key into a service bin as you leave.The one thing I did like about the this hotel was the price. Staying at the APA Hotel Shinjuku Gyoemmae taught me that I could put up with the other disappointments to save money.The other good thing about this hotel is the location. It's really close to Nichome, Isetan Shinjuku and other fun places. It's also one minute to the train station so it was super convenient moving around from the hotel.

The bed took almost all of the bedroom space. There was no closet and no space for suitcases. We only had 2 carryons and no large luggages so we put them on the desk.Bathroom was very tight too. Breakfast was very good but there are lot of restaurants nearby with more reasonable price.

Good and convenient location and clean room. We were at first given a very small twin room but moved to a slightly bigger one upon my request. We were there for eight nights; I came to Japan for 8 days, but my son for 3 weeks (had been there for 2 weeks when I arrived). We had 2 large suitcases plus 2 cabin suitcases. Even with the larger twin room, we struggled placing the luggage. No lobby for sitting, so either you have to stay in your crummy room or go out.

The rooms are very small, only suitable for a few nights. The location was good though. It does have an onsen which was good. The rooms were clean. Service at the counter was good with the staff speaking decent English.

The location of the hotel is fantastic being walkable to lots of attractions and tourist destinations in Shinjuku. Train station within a few minutes walk to connect you to the major Shinjuku station which is one station away. Lots of staff at the hotel for check in. The check in process is quite strange, you get a hotel key from staff and check yourself in with a touch screen. My booking had an error and I couldn’t check in (I’d already paid and it was asking me to pay again). Staff fixed the issue quickly and apologised for the issue. The only things to consider for this hotel is that the rooms are tiny. Unless you’ve visited Japan before the room size might shock you. There is room for a bag and a person to stand. With two or more people in the room it gets a little claustrophobic. The other consideration is that the lifts are very popular and at peak periods you might wait 5-10 mins to be able to use the lift. Self check out key drop was a great experience. Would stay again. Especially if you keep your eyes on the specials for this hotel sometimes you can get a great price.For Beer lovers. Check out Highbury the home of beer (awesome craft beer) and also Vector Beer (you will have to pay a seat fine to sit down here “Otoshi” of about $4 AUD for each person which gives you a small bite size meal in exchange for sitting).

The sento bathouse was very clean and spacious enough and a great place to relax after a day out. APA Gyoemmae offers good value for money in Tokyo and is well located. Efficiently run and well equipped to look after your baggage before and after check-in with a secure tag system. Rooms are compact but well designed and provide all accessories [fridge, good wifi, hairdryer, bathroom cosmetics, robe, slippers etc etc] but no safe for valuables which seems to be the way things are in most Tokyo hotels.

We stayed at the hotel for 6 nights from the UK. It's located ideally for exploring Tokyo with the main Shinjuku station less than 10 minutes easy, flat walk away as well as a subway station on the same block with a line running to Tokyo station.The hotel itself is spotless and the staff are extremely helpful. The room was small but still big enough for both of us to have our luggage open. The bathroom is compact but functional. (Having read other reviews beforehand - I expected the room to be small... so why would I now mark them down because of it?)The Narita Express stops at Shinjuku main station which we walked in under 10 minutes with our luggage in tow. The reception staff handily helped us with a luggage forwarding service for some £14 we left our luggage with them and it got sent onto our next hotel in Nagoya which meant we could travel with just our hand luggage. Very handy!The pizzeria and 100 yen shop across the road are extremely handy!

We were in tokyo for 4 nights and this hotel was ideal. It was right near a metro stop and you could get to the main station within a 15 minute walk. We arrived into tokyo at midnight and got the bus to the main station (Shinjuku) and then we walked to the hotel as there was no other transport to take us there. The hotel is great, Clean (Small rooms) But all rooms are small in Tokyo. Personally pay the extra for the larger room as it is a tight squeeze. There is plenty of places to eat nearby. I would stay at this hotel again as it was clean and modern which is my style.

I really love the location of this hotel as it is only a 2 minute walk to the subway station and it's only 2 subway stops away from Shinjuku. There's also a park in the vicinity. Room and bathroom was really well equipped (I was shocked at the variety of bathroom amenities the hotel actually provided). The only issue I had was the extremely flat pillows that had NO support AT ALL. I had to fold the pillow in half in order to sleep.WiFi is decent if you are not doing stuff that eats up the bandwidth. Or else it would be slow.Overall a good place if you are spending the entire day out and only spending the night in the hotel.

Nice hotel, clean and comfortable. In very good location just a short walk from Shinjuku station, Gyoemmae park and Isetan shopping centre. Also has an in-house restaurant and self-checkin kiosks which is practical in addition to laundry in the basement. All in all a very good and priceworthy alternative.

Booked this hotel for two pax in each room, but my family changed to another hotel so I stayed in a room just for myself. I think the room is too small for two persons (even if you book a double bed), but it's okay for one person. Pros:+ Very close to Shinjuku shopping area (Muji, Uniqlo, Maruei, etc.) and there are many cafes, convenience stores, and other small shops nearby+ Very close to metro Marunouchi line + Calm area+ A very complete amenities in each room. I personally appreciate the hair band. Very good quality and not many hotels provide them. Hairdryer, mini fridge, and water boiler available.Cons:- Very busy hotel, lots of guests. Check in and check out was a bit madness during rush hour.- Very small (narrow) reception area- Waiting for elevator was a bit long (due to guests going up and down, the laundry and public bath is located in the basement)- The rooms are really jammed packed, narrow hall, and limited wiew from the window. During my stay, I experienced fire alarm in the morning (and we had to wait about 5-10 minutes) which apparently triggered by steam from one of the guest's bathroom.

Stayed here recently for one night and although the rooms are small even by Tokyo standards the convenient location more than made up for it. Highly recommended, but make sure your suitcase isn’t too big.

Our experience was great. Location was great and the place was clean. The room was what you expected Japan- small and cozy. If you're staying here, check out the restaurant/bar right across the hotel.

Very good location, good place for overnight,clean ,excellent price. Bathroom is very clean provides pj, bathrub, sleepers etc Small rooms not a surprise. Will come back for short stay only. Close to excellent shopping center, good variety of restaurants specially for breakfast and easy access to train station. First visit to Japan .

I read the reviews about how tiny the rooms are and assumed we would be ok as my mom and I are both pretty small (5'1 tall). We booked a double room (1 full-size bed) for four days. I felt so claustrophobic and DREADED coming back to the room each night. If you've ever been on a cruise, I'd have to say the room and bathrooms are much smaller than the rooms on the ship. The window was tiny and we could barely get any natural light in. The room is so smal that their is a sign in the bathroom stating that one should keep the bathroom door closed when showering or else the steam might trigger the the sprinklers to go off (what?!). The bathroom was even smaller. The faucet for the shower and sink were connected, so you turn one on, the other turns on. However, I have to give the hotel props for cleanliness. It was very clean. When we opted out of getting our room cleaned, hotel staff would always leave a bag of toiletries outside our door (a plus). Also, the wi-fi was TERRIBLE. It was slow, inconsistent, most of the didnt even work, and did not work for us after 10pm. Also only one outlet and two USB ports in the room. Front desk staff was not friendly. We had trouble making reservations to a restaurant in Shibuya and asked the front desk to help. Their response "Sorry, we don't make reservations". However, the wouldn't even help us/answer questions about how to use the room phone. Location was great. The subway station was only a few steps away and we easily took the subway to and from the airport and throughout Tokyo. Also, very close to the large shopping streets of Shinjuku. Summary: I am not sure how large the other rooms are, but I would NOT recommend booking a double room at this hotel. If you can get a larger room, I would recommend this hotel based on the location and cleaniness. However, if you need wi-fi for travel research or work, the wifi was terrible, you may want to look elsewhere.

Overall we had a pleasant stay at the hotel. The staffs were extremely helpful. They called us when our luggage was delivered, and helped us merge 2 bookings into 1 so we don't have to check out twice. The room was very clean. If you put a "do not disturb" sign, they would left bags of new towels and toiletries for you. The public bath and swimming pools were nice! They also had coin laundry onsite, which was very much needed. It is 1-2 mint walk to a Toei subway station. There are not a lot of restaurant choices around, but they do have 2 convenient stores nearby. In the guest rooms, there were some Japan nationalist propaganda materials denying Japan's involvement in Pearly Harbor Attack and Nanking Massacre. That was really a turnoff for us. Be aware of that if you don't feel like spending money and financially support such institution.

We found some of the staff not very pleasant at the front desk. One would ask something and they would talk in Japanese as if talking about you. And the ones I spoke to had very limited English.The rooms were immaculate albeit extremely small. Don't come here with 2 big suit cases as one just about has to go in the hallway.Free internet which is nice.The tv is mostly in Japanese, even the CNN and UK channels, very annoying. And there is no translation for anything in the room.Breakfast being a vegan was okay, although soy milk would have been nice to have.There was a tiny window which I could not open but I believe looked straight at the wall 1 meter away of the next building.The temperature in the hallways where the rooms were was stifling..no aircon...very bad I though...The tiny bathroom with the tiny bathtub was cute, was enough for me but if one is old and cannot step into the bath one cannot take a shower.The baths downstairs were fabulous.

Great location, clean and quiet rooms, friendly staff. The room was the smallest I'd seen in Japan and with me by myself, only one suitcase and a backpack, I felt crowded in the space. BUT, I wasn't in Tokyo to hang out in the hotel room so it definitely met the need for a nice place to sleep and shower.

Hotel was very clean and staff super nice and polite. Rooms and toilet are very small which can get a bit annoying at times, when there´s no room to move. Bed was comfy, but pillow was super thin so I recommed you to bring x-tra pillow with you. If you would like to use hotel spa be sure you don´t have any tattoos.

We stayed in this APA hotel for a couple of nights. The location is great, as it is relatively close to the bustling hub of Shinjuku, as well as being walking distance from Shinjuku gyoenmae station, and Shinjuku gyoen itself. There are heaps of convenience stores and food options around too! The room size is standard for APA hotel- very narrow and small. However, the bed, pillows and bathroom were very good. I also got the chance to try the public spa area which I definitely enjoyed a lot! Checking in and out was quite efficient, and the hotel provides all the amenities I need (except it would be great if they could give 2 water bottles a day instead of one). All in all, I enjoyed my stay here and would definitely stay again!

We were very satisfied with the location and the cleanliness of the hotel. The rooms are very small but it does not feel claustrophobic due to the interior design. However, it is a bit of a squeeze if you have twin sharing. We had individual rooms so it was fine. Near the hotel there are local grocery store, family marts, clinic, pharmacy and reasonable local food/ resturants that open till 6 am in the morning. Most restaurant operators understand simple English and English menu is available. I highly recommend the gyoza shop across the road. The food is delicious, service is good and price very reasonable.4 minutes' walk away is the shinjuku san chome station that connects to many major train lines and further down the road is the shinjuku train and bus station that connects to the airport. The hotel is a stone's throw away from the nearest train station. That is a plus point if you are travelling light. But we were greatly shocked that we had to lug our heavy luggage up 2 flights of stairs to exit the train station.Both exits 1 and 2 have neither escalators or lifts. And to access the lift on the opposite side of the platform (exit 3) you need to walk up and down another 2 flights of stairs. If you have a heavy luggage or need a lift, it is best to exit at the shinjuku sanchome station then walk to the hotel. I'll definitely go back to the same hotel if i stay in Tokyo again.

Small room for two, it was hard to store my luggage. Onsen(japanese bath) was exactly what you see in the pictures.Clean hotel with great location, 2min walk to Shinjuku Gyoen park also across the street from Shinjuku nichome. Walking distance to Shinjuku shops, restaurants and metro station.* Wi-fi* Quick check out* Friendly staff* Shiseido products + shower caps, tooth brush, hair tie, robe and slippers

First of all, our hotel room was extremely small, just enough room for a double bed and desk. There was also a mini fridge and a very nice bathroom with lovely Shiseido products. Also provided were slippers to take home, and robes. The bed was very comfortable as were the very thin pillows. It was also extremely quiet. I never heard anything from adjoining rooms. Free WiFi is included and there is a large TV with at least one English station (BBC International).It took a minute or so to check in, most of the time was making copies of our passports. I guess because our stay was pre-paid, checking out was even faster - our room access cards went into a card reader, and we were done.The room was spotless when checking in, and every day after. I cannot commend the housekeeping staff enough. The hotel location is very good, a 10 minute walk at most to the Shinjuku station, and even closer to 2 other subway stations on the M line.The hotel has a restaurant and spa which we didn't use, but wished we did.Overall, it was an excellent 3 night stay and a great way to start our 10 day Japan adventure.

2 out of 5 starsNice new hotel, value for money, but let down by the worst pillows I’ve ever slept on (and I was a Boy Scout!). The deluxe double rooms at 11m2 were very small, even by Tokyo standards, making it a life sized game of Tetris to simultaneously open suitcases, or get dressed, or even have a cup of tea and a chat. The length of the double bed set the width of the room, which gives you an idea of what you’re up for. The pillow (and you can safely assume I’m using air quotes when using that word, plus potentially some significant eye rolling) was little more than a plump, yet somehow hard, tea-towel sized slab of cotton. Shockingly uncomfortable. So much so, at 3am on the first night I was rifling through my suitcase (which I had fallen over despite trying my best to wedge under the desk) to see if I could find a rolled up jumper to use as an alternative. I did ask at Reception for a different pillow, or even a second terrible one, but they couldn’t help. Epically bad.My other niggle was that the tap in the bathroom that is used to control both the water to both the wash basin and the shower is around the wrong way. This means when you are trying to turn off the tap you are actually turning it on even more. So if you’re in the shower the sudden blast of water will damn near take your head off, or if you’re attempting to wash your hands, you end up with an alarmingly vigorous stream of piping hot water all over your groinal area. We ate brekky in the hotel once during our stay and at it was reasonable, if unspectacular. Cornflakes were available which in Japan is hard to find, and was very welcome after days of eating lord knows what. ¥1600 well spent.Overall the hotel was good. Location was excellent, rooms were clean albeit hilariously small, and it was reasonable value for money. If I’d brought my own pillow I’d give it 4 stars, but sadly I’ve had to deduct 2 stars because I had to rest my enormous noggin on a small mat rather than a pillow. I would stay again, but only if APA buy new pillows, or if I bring my own.

Went in the room to sleep and shower of course, so it served its purpose. The rooms were tiny and very hard to maneuver around. No place to store clothing either - except hooks.Great Price & location!

Conveniently located hotel in the heart of Shinjuku. Easy check in and good price. I do warn though the rooms are TINY. We had a double and the bed is the length of the room. We had three suitcases and it was a tight squeeze. The bed was incredibly comfortable and the room house keeping was immaculate. Also loved the room immenties and Shiseido products within !

Me and a friend spent 5 night in this hotel. Room was very small as expected (every hotel you book in Japan has the dimension of the room well stated), it’s hard to move around the room with the luggage open but nothing tragic. Bathroom was tiny as well. Apart from that, hotel is new and well furnished, bedroom was amazingly comfortable and there is also a SPA. We lost a passport on a train and the assistants at the front desk had been very helpful making all the calls to find it. Metro is right in front and two stops away from Shinjuku. Considering we payed half the price of most of the hotels with the same services, I would definitely recommend it.

This hotel is considered a business hotel, which means that the rooms are quite small but we managed well enough for the three days we were there. We kept our suitcases piled one on the other. It has excellent access to the subways and is a short block into Shinjuku Gyoemmae Park. Staff was friendly. There were lots of eating establishments and grocery stores nearby. There is an onsen on site plus it has a coin laundry. The rooms were well equipped with toiletries.

My wife and I were reading reviews of this hotel as we were travelling back to Tokyo and people seem obsessed with the room being "tiny". In our experience of staying in Shinjuku, this seems like a pretty standard sized room. But then again, we book a hotel to sleep somewhere close to the places we want to visit (or near a good transport link, such as Shinjuku Station), we don't want anything more from our room. Maybe a cup of coffee in the morning and a shower.This hotel had very handy coffee bags (think tea bags, but for coffee) and a great shower.Yes, you pretty much have to live out of your case, but we were fine with that for the 5 nights we were there.The bed was comfortable, the hotel had very reasonably priced laundry facilities, and was in a fantastic location. For a bit over £300 for five nights, I challenge anyone to find better value in a major city centre - you'd probably not get an AirBNB for that in London.Anyway, if you're looking for a base to explore Tokyo and the surrounding area, I'd be happy to recommend this - if you have reasonable expectations.

I like the location of the hotel. It’s in a not too busy/crowded street so less noise but still close to the subway and the big park behind it. Stores and eateries are also within easy walking distance from it. Rooms are a bit cramped so big luggages are a no-no.Free breakfast menu has nice assortment of dishes but was the same everyday during my 7 days stay. Food was good but maybe adding/changing some of the dishes would be ideal.

PROS:Location - Close to a metro station, super close to the Shinjuku Gyoen, walking distance to plenty of food, convenience stores, and shopping.There's also a small temple 2 block away.Comfortable - The bed was comfy, and the rooms had most amenities you would need on a tripEfficient - check in and check out were a breeze. The hotel receptionists were helpful, and the housekeeping staff very thorough in their workCONS:Cramped - the rooms are small, like maneuvering through a maze. The bathrooms are smaller (cute tub, which is bigger than one i've seen in a japanese home, but small by western standards) and my brother who's 6'2" had trouble in the shower/tub areaSpotty internet - the wifi in our room was a little troublesome. We rented out a wifi stick at the airport and that had better speeds than the one in the hotel.They do have a public bath in the basement as well. Which is a nice little Japanese tradition one might like to try

this hotel so far good. Food, location, privacy room, clean, near subway stationBut this hotel have shortage for small room. The hotel also do not have have wardrobe, so the clohes just hanging at the place provided

This hotel tries to give the impression it is a decent standard “international” hotel. In reality it is suitable only for one night for very junior businessmen or women prepared to live in a tiny space lacking in any form of basic comforts. We expect small rooms in Tokyo but these are beyond anything. 11sq m for a ‘double room’. No wardrobe, just two hooks and four hangers. No drawers. No bedside tables. One tiny desk and chair. The bathroom was just tiny and is included in the 11 sq m. There is only one tap that serves both shower and mini basin. We had 14 nights here. No wonder they demand prepayment on arrival before you see your room. It was the worst fortnight of our extensive travels anywhere in the world. We literally had to take turns to stand up and dress. We had to pile our luggage by the door and move it to get out. You cannot even Store a suitcase under the bed. It is on a sort of platform. You have to crawl over each other to get off the bed. There is no hotel lobby area, just a check in desk. No seating area at all in the hotel. The restaurant / bar has very limited opening hours and you cannot even sit in there in between times. Good points? Very small but comfy bed. Clean room. I cannot warn strongly enough against staying here for more than one night with just a quick change of clothes. Simply appalling. I understand the Apa in Yokohama is as bad if not worse. Thank god we chose the magnificent New Grand there. See glowing review.

The hotel is near malls (just a few blocks away), there's a national garden near it and there are a lot of restaurants nearby. 2 blocks away is the Shinjuku-gyoenmae station. The room is a bit small but if you plan to go out after breakfast and not stay in your room then it will be fine. The breakfast food is the same everyday with one or two changes each day. There's a vending machine at the Basement Floor 1 but with little choices.

This hotel is great if you don't plan to spend much time in your room! It is clean, the staff are friendly and it is in a great location, but my bedroom was pretty tiny. I didn't have the breakfast option, as there are so many places to eat (as well as convenience stores) really close by. It was easy to walk to lots of interesting places and you can be in the pulsing heat of Shinjuku, in a few minutes. It was perfect for my 2 night stay in Tokyo and easy to walk from the station.

The hotel is clean and in a good location, however the room is so tiny that we only had one place to lay our suit case which took up our only room to move around. The bathroom is incredibly tiny as well.

We booked our tour through Intrepid so they chose the hotels. Some were excellent but this one, sadly wasn't. First things first, the overwhelming problem with this hotel is the size of the rooms. Honestly, I've stayed in hotels all over the world and this is by far the smallest room I've ever stayed in. You could literally wake up and make a cup of tea FROM YOUR BED!!The room aside, I didn't find any of the staff particulary welcoming or warming. At no point during my 4 night stay, did I ever feel wanted there as a customer, more that I was a hindrenece and in the way. That goes from the reception staff to the staff in the restuarant, who it appears their main job is to get you in, feed you and get you out as quickly as possible. I could forgive it lacking any kind of facilities (but it did have a downstairs spa) if it had charm and character, but sadly no. This was a cold, clinical chain hotel with tiny rooms, unfreindly staff and no character at all. If I ever go back to Japan, I certainly wouldn't choose this place to stay at again.The only positive thing I'll say about it is that it's in a great location, but equally, so will many other hotels that offer so much more.

I stayed for 7 nights in April 2017 in this hotel. The hotel is located near the Shinjuku-Koen (Park); close enough to walk to Shinjuku but far enough to avoid the hustle and bustle of this party district. The subway is 200 metres away on the Marunouchi Line and stations like Shibuya and Ueno are 15 minutes away by train. The staff was really friendly and discrete. This huge hotel has decent rooms, although a bit small. I stayed in a room for 2 persons on my own and I am glad I did. Bathroom is tiny and you do not have a lot of space to stow your luggage away. There is a large array of bathing products, toothbrushes, shaving equipment... Beds are soft but have flat pillows. VOD-system and a large tv are also available.On the B1-floor there is a hot tub, vending machines, washing machines and a dryer and a microwave. Everything is very tidy and the cleaning staff does a great job here. Coffee, tea and water are freely available. The hotel is also a great starting point for clubbing and partying. Shinjuku is easily accessible (but if you do not want to walk a mile, I recommend to pay close attention to the time tables of the subway. Last train is around midnight). For those who like to explore the famous Ni-Chome Gay district, it is literally at your door step 300 metres away. For those who hesistate because of it, no worries, the gay district is kept discretely away in a few alleys and no one is bothering you.

The hotel is close to metro and the Shinjuku commercial area. Room is very small. The bath area is decent. I was busy touring the city and didn't stay in the small hotel room much. In the last morning of my stay, I had some time to check the room and was shocked by the politically charged books and magazines staged in my room. I assumed every room has the same setup. The owner of the APA chain seemed to be very vocal in propagating right-wing agenda. Among the reading material was a Apple Town magazine. It calls for militarizing Japan. In a book Cherry Blossoms In The Wind in my hotel's desk drawer, war criminals were commemorated and their suicide missions against allies were glorified. One of his another provided free book Japan Pride III - Theoretical Modern History, author denied Nanking Massacre, defamed comfort women as prostitutes and claimed they were well paid and better managed when Japanese took over the operation, and claimed that the Peal Harbor bobming was an American conspiracy. I believe that people can proclaime that coal is white and snow is black. But to force feed guests the history distortion in his own hotel chain? No way. I regret not knowing earlier about Toshio Motoya (元谷 外志雄) and his controversial political view and practice. He can keep it to himself. But don't use your business to force hotel customers to read your horse shtick. I decide not to use their service in my future visit to Japan.

The room was immaculately clean with great facilities. The toiletries were high-quality which was a great surprise. The location was also really good, it was within walking distance of popular areas. Very easy to get places.

Stayed there for 5 nights. Location is very good with 7/11 and family mart with a very close metro. Breakfast was tasty and with several options too. Room size and amenities was good enough for me. The luggage storing facility is quite nice. Also empty box option for carrying back extra baggage is fine.however, after checking out, I had to wait for 30 minutes for my friend to come with her car to pick me up. There's no proper area for waiting/sitting. When I wanted to sit, I was told there's no such place.

My family and I stayed here due to its central location, everything was easily accessible by foot. Check in and check out are all automated (via machine system) Rooms are clean and well equipped, the only let down was the size of the rooms which were tiny. We didn't have any room for luggage, we had to place it on the study desk, but other than that I would recommend this hotel.

The hotel is located in a easy to find location but check in is difficult. First you line up to give details to reception but they don’t actually check you in. You then need to go to the checking ‘atm’ looking machines to finalise and pay. We tried to find someone where for a massage as we had just been skiing and reception referred us to a flyer in the room Instead of providing details over phone. Then the flyer was in Japanese, so couldn’t understand it. The rooms were quite small, not much room around bed or bathroom - but they were clean and had everything you need. Breakfast was ok, a mix of traditional Japanese food and western. When leaving we asked if they could call us taxis as we had a lot of luggage. They said no, told us to flag one on street. Overall the property was ok, but every experience with actual staff was difficult.

I already knew staying in Shinjuku that for a decent priced hotel I would have to sacrifice a bit on hotel room size but no AC!? First of we got a smoking room since there were no more non smoking room and the window only opens about 4 inches wide! It was so difficult to sleep at night I mean what kind of hotel doesn't have ac... besides from this point hotel location was in a good location and staff were nice to us. That's it would I stay again? Hell no

Hotel is fine if you're only planning on sleeping in your room and spending the day out exploring. Good location. Room was tiny, and I mean tiny. They just about could squeeze a double bed in there, but this meant there was barely any room to stand...

It was my first time to Japan. My friend suggest this nice hotel with free hot spring facility. It takes around 10 minutes from Tokyo Station. Room is quite small but functional, suitable for just one person. Shopping mall and restaurants were nearby with 5 minutes walk. Efficient staff at reception.

First room stunk of damp and had a window that opened out on to a wall... got a room change next day and second room was much better with some natural light although the bathroom light flickered.Location is really good - gyoza restaurant across the road is recommended although you might have to queue with the locals to get in. Short walk to Shinjuku station and very close to the beautiful gyoen park.Can hear doors slamming and corridor at night.Overall not somewhere to treat your girlfriend to on a romantic break but if you are spending most of the time out and about in Tokyo then this place is ok for the price.

I don't know which was worse but let me start with the Japanese propaganda booklet glamourising the war I found insidiously placed in the drawer, for a hotel business that caters to international visitors, this makes me very uncomfortable. I understood it a little as it was in Japanese and my partner who is fluent in Japanese, said it made him very angry and he is against businesses that are racist <-- now for a successful chain of hotels in Japan, this word is very strong and it shows how insensitive APA hotel chain is to people from all walks of life and of many other nationalities. We felt this was anti-chinese. The wifi was bad for me too, sure it worked fine for maybe an hour or less, but after that it wouldn't give me internet even though I was clearly connected. I contacted frontdesk again and the lady kindly came up to my room to show me on her phone that the wifi is clearly working for her and she is unable to help me with why mine does not work. I figured it out on my own later that I had to disable VPN for the public hotel wifi to work. They should allow VPNs to work with public wifi because we want to protect our privacy especially when using a network that other people can access with the same password! How stupid! The way the staff handled payment was bad (please note this is a pre-payment hotel), the staff tried to push me towards a payment MACHINE? to self pay?? How many foreigners will be able to use a payment machine in Japan with their cards and how many foreign credit cards will have a PIN number to be used together? I can't remember mine either as I use it as a credit card -meaning you just hand it over and the charge is made. Simple, why do they try to complicate payment for foreign tourists?It made me feel like the guy at the front desk just wants to have as little contact with guests as possible. Is this an upscale motel? Sure feels like it at this point. Nobody to even help you with your luggage. There is also no view at all. I pulled back the curtains on the small horizontal window above the bed and it shows the stairwell of the next building. It was also hard to find what number to call for the frontdesk (7) I believe it was written in japanese somewhere. Oh and there is no room service, so really, I might as well stay in an airbnb, cheaper, payment is no hassle, communication is prompt and in English, and most importantly the host will be so much more helpful thatn an impersonal anti-chinese hotel chain. The good points? The artificial hotspring on the basement was good, the beds were soft and comfy, the rooms and facilities seem clean. Not too far from the station. But at the end of it, that anti-chinese war propaganda booklet made what would have been a passably pleasant stay, a bad experience. My partner said I should never stay at APA hotels again because now that we know they are pandering to such propaganda, how can we or ANYONE support such ideology or support the politicisation of a commercial hotel business for international travellers by staying at any APA hotel chain?

Very good location, near Shinjuku rail station and metro. Many restaurants and convenience stores within a 1 minute walk. Check in was very friendly, as the clerk immediately recognized that we would need help with the kiosk that dispensed our room keys. Price was as advertised, no alterations as sometimes occurs. Room is definitely tiny and a logistic challenge for 2 suitcases. However, with a little imagination, it all worked out well. Bathroom is tiny but efficient. Excellent power in the shower. High end toilet, a delight for us from North America. Bed was very comfortable. Small flat pillow allowed for various configurations. Bar fridge in the room helped to keep water and soft drinks nicely cold. Good electrical outlets. Breakfast was included with our rate. Very nice selection of Japanese items, with labels in English. Also scrambled eggs, French fries. Great buns. Fabulous coffee. A variety of juices. Friendly staff everywhere.

It was out first time to Tokyo . We decided to stay in Shinjuku since it’s central to everything . Found this Hotel on TA . The Check in process was a little confusing . Once u talk to a person than you are instructed to use a Kiosk station . The photos of the room are deceiving . TINY room and bathroom . Cramped for 2 people . Can hear everything in Hallway . Location good . Not great for comfortablity 3 Star

I stayed there for 5 nights after traveling from Osaka. It is very modern hotel and the location is superb, which is very near to the Shinjuku Gyoenmae station and a bit further away is Shinjuku station for both JR and subway. There are cafes, shops, restaurants and convenient stores around. The only thing I hate was most of the time heating (I guessed it is central) air conditioning system and the pillows are way tooooo thin. But the rest I have go to say it is quite good compare to its price.

We were offered free drinks on check-in. These were to be redeemed in the restaurant. When my partner and I went to the restaurant, I ordered a Perrier, and he ordered a glass of mineral water.When the drinks came, we were asked what food we would be ordered. When we said that we just wanted drinks, my partner was told that if he didn’t order an alcoholic beverage, then we would have to leave.We left.Other than that, the room was tiny, but functional. The bed was comfortable, though we had to request thicker pillows. (My partner said “What is the point of these flat, hard pillows?” I explained that it must be a Japanese thing.)The ofuro (or bath) in the basement was lovely.

Just stayed here five nights. * Good location* Many noted the small room size. They are small if you compare them to western hotel rooms but compared to Japanese ones their decent.* Under two mins walk to nearest metro station* Staff are friendly and helpful* Shampoo conditioner and body wash provided and are decent quality. * Loads of usual personal use products like earbuds, combs etc provided. Even body wash sponges provided Daily.* Plenty of convenience stores at under two mins walk.* Only two power outlets in room so I recommend power boards.* Fridge provided but no safe storage boxes* Air purifier/purifier inside but buttons in Japanese. Model is Panasonic vx40h2 if u wanted to research how it works. * No storage cupboards just wall mounted hooks * Tully's just up the road great for coffee * There is a dumpling restaurant across the road which looks busy and good but I didn't get chance to tryMy only complaint here was that the cleaning staff broke my power converter :)

i stayed for 2 nights ...the location was good and 10 minutes walk to shinjuku station ... i know hotel in tokyo is always have small room .. but i think this one a a bit small ... luckily i travel with my wife .. but i don't think suitable if travel if friend etc ... but when you come to Tokyo .. you want to experience the place and cultural .. check-in and check-out were smooth ...

I've stayed in many hotels in Tokyo specifically in the Shinjuku area. This was one of the smaller of hotels I've stayed in this area. However, it was big enough for two average size adults.The bathroom was also small, but enough room for one person. All the usual amenities were provided - toothbrushes, razors, brush, etc.Our room did not offer a view of the city. Instead, the view was a wall. If you would like a view, it doesn't hurt to ask when you check in.There is a restaurant attached to the hotel. A free drink coupon was provided when I checked in.Also, there is a sauna on the bottom floor of the hotel that is available to guests. I, however, did not have time to use it.

We stayed in APA Hotel Shinjuku Gyoen-mae for 4 nights which were quite okay. Everything nice and clean, though the room was even tinier than expected (we did expect a tiny room in a Tokio hotel, but there wasn't even a closet to put your clothes or a place to store our bags). The room had a window, but it was made of milk glass, so not sure what kind of view we would have had. In general, the room was quiet. But, as to be expected, once people start changing rooms at night and knocking on each others doors, you will wake up from it (as happened to us on Friday and Saturday night).

Good hotel for a short stay. Got a bit cramped for 2 people but that is normal for Japan. Good value and staff were helpful as they seemed to be at the Reception all night long. Make sure you request a non-smoking room!

APA hotel provided a quick check in and out, a secure lodging and deserves bonus remarks for having their own public bath/ onsen. It's exactly what you need after a long days worth of shopping in downtown Shinjuku. Shinjuku gyoenmae (gardens) are just behind the hotel and from our room we had a great view. Their in house restaurant also serves up great steaks! It is a great place to use as base whilst travelling in Tokyo having access to Shinjuku JR station (10min walk) and metro (3mins walk) so close by. There are amazing restaurants within walking distance and you are even lucky to have a great gyoza restaurant across the street. Would be happy to stay here again.

We quite liked our stay at this APA hotel. It is conveniently located around 5 minutes walk or less away from Shinjuku gyoenmae station and is right beside the amazing Shinjuku gyoen gardens! Shinjuku station and entertainment and shopping area is around 10 minutes walk away! There are various eateries near the hotel too. It is a very convenient base to explore Tokyo from. The room was quite nice but quite small and narrow as expected. I like how this hotel has an onsen (Grand Spa), which was an added bonus to our stay. Check-in and check-out is quite easy and staff are quite friendly and ready to help. Overall it is on the expensive side for a business hotel but still quite good and enjoyable.

I like this hotel because it's near Shinjuku Gyoemmae (gardens), the rooms are spotless and the check-in is fast!. All the employees are very helpful and respectful. There is much shopping, eating and entertainment just a few minutes walk and multiple subway and train lines in the area.

Love the facilities, from the public onzen, to the laundry machine, the room was small but it was condusive. My only bad remark and hope they do change it was the mattress for the beds, they are so soft that u sunk in. It would be a awesome place overall with a good bed.

This APA hotel within 10 minutes walking distance from Shinjuku Station apprears to be well set up to handle foreign visitors. I saw a lot of them there during my 3 night stay. The hotel has friendly, welcoming staff that speak english with ease. The whole mood of the hotel seems to be rather bright and cheery. I rather enjoyed the short walk to Shinjuku station, which leads you past shops and restaurants and a nice selection of small businesses. I chose a room with a double bed that filled up most of the floorspace, but when staying in this part of Tokyo there is so much to see out on the street, that lounging in your hotel room is really not the best use of your time. I have stayed in two other APA hotels in Japan previously and i would rate this one as the best so far.

Location wise for the hotel is a plus point. Loved the way they provided services like hot onzen@public bath,coin laundry service(washer and dryer),microwave. The down side of this hotel is the bed provided,is sunken and not a place to get a good night sleep after a long day of walking and exploring.Pillows definitely needs to be replaced.Despite all love the freshness Burger restaurant next door.

I got what I expected as a first time user of APA in Tokyo... a bed, a desk, a bathroom that was slightly hazardous, and a good nights rest in a central location. If you want something extra, this place has it with a restaurant onsite and a small sauna (hardly an onsen as described). Solid place with a metro station one block away down a side street or two blocks on the main drag. Walk ten minutes and you are at the main Shinjuku Station, so location was great. Walk two blocks, and you are at Gyommae Park. Could have gone daily if I didn't have other things to explore. Would stay again at APA and this location for sure.

I stayed in a single non-smoking room. The room was v clean. Although small, it had everything I needed (hair-dryer, fridge). If you have a large suitcase, it might be a bit of an issue to have your suitcase open all the time. Bathroom was v clean as well. Toilet has bidet options! Breakfast buffet (optional) was good (Jap & Western). There is also a communal Japanese bath on the premise. I didn't use it but it looked very clean.

I stayed 5 night in this APA hotel in Shinjuku. APA has many APA hotels in various districts of Tokyo and Osaka. I booked the one double-bed room. Check in was fine. It was a small room for one double bed slipped right up to a wall and a dresser/desk just 2 feet from the bed. Just barely enough room to set up my one luggage behind the door. I would not recommend two person to stay in this room due to the space issue. Clean room/bathroom. Firm bed, and yes, the pillows are bit flat and bit hard but that's OK for me. Best part about this hotel is its location. It is only 5 blocks from the Shinjuku subway exit and easy walking distance to the shopping and bar/food districts. Overall, a good choice for lower price range hotel and I got good value from it. I enjoyed my stay there and I would stay there again next time I'm in Tokyo.

Ideal Location. Spotless white duvet cover and bed sheets, Shiseido brand amenity in the bathroom were advantages.Disadvantages... - Reception was cramped and busy, as same as other APA hotel. - Weird design of the building. There is an Atrium? or just open ceiling hole? in this building, which is surrounded by guest rooms. Corridor was wet and cold in rainy day.- A book equipped in the guest room, written by Mr.Motoya (President of APA Group), wouldn't help to ease guest's mind.To be honest, I've been keeping away from APA hotel chain till this time...

This hotel has small rooms, which are clean and nicely decorated. There is barely room for a suitcase in the twin room. The location was good, but be mindful as to which exit you must leave the train station. If your room gets hot you can insist on them turning on the air conditioner. We were told to open the window as it was not working! Once we insisted they switched it on. Very unusual to us, but maybe not there. We found the location and price very appealing.

The room is very tiny. You can open maximum of 2 medium luggage inside the room. The pillows are horrible. (Super flat) so bring your own neck pillow if you want a good sleep or get a better pillow from the front desk. The room aircon is not cold, the temperature outside the room is cooler than inside the room. Their tv is of no use, all their programs are mostly in Japanese and their channels are boring to max. If you wan entertainment, download your own movie if you wan to watch anything. If not, just be like us, go out the whole day and don't go back unless you are very tired. (Haha) Their hotel only gave ONE bottle of mineral water everyday and should you request for it at front desk, you will be charge 100yen. (Buy at 7-11 or family mart better) Be prepared to go up and down a lot of stairsway especially the subway stations. (So try to keep your luggage minimum if possible) This hotel is in the middle of 2 subway station. Nearest station is shinjuku gyoemmae station which is about 2mins walk. Another one which is about 7mins walk is shinjuku sanchome station.

Great hotel and staff. Amazing view! The only negative thing was the room, very small but comfortable in some way! The price is correct. I haven’t tried the breakfast. The hotel is situated in a good position, useful for having Japanese breakfast and dinner.

I stayed here in October of 2017. I had a small single room with a fridge and Good WiFi. I did not like the step up bathroom as the floor gets slippery and one could fall coming out of the bathroom. Very Tiny as well as most hotels in Tokyo are. I have stayed at two others and this one had the smallest bathroom. Lots of amenities including washer/dryer in the basement as well as a Spa. Good for the Price and Location.

The APA Shinjuku Gyommae is a typical Japanese business hotel close to the Shinjuku Gyoen National Park. There's a metro station and many shops and restaurants nearby. So, the location of the hotel is quite convenient. Our room was as small as expected, still it provided everything you need. However, I really disliked that the window in our room had a frosted glass screen. Thus, you could not look outside and got hardly any day light in the room. This circumstance made the room even more claustrophobic. If you are a vampire, however, you will feel really comfortable here.

Was in Tokyo sightseeing for a week. Location is pretty decent- close to Shinjuku (~10 min walk) and about 100ft from a red line Tokyo Metro stop.Arrived at Haneda airport at 6am and it took almost two hours and two transfers to get to the hotel by train. We weren't able to check in that early, but the hotel offered to let us leave bags in the lobby until check-in, and recognized the 2hr early check-in as offered by our online travel agency. It happened to be raining upon arrival and one of the front desk representatives went in back, and brought out umbrellas for us to use- very appreciated!When we got back in the early afternoon, check-in was pretty straight forward. You stop by the front desk where they ask to take a scan of your passports, then are handed a single keycard. To complete check-in, you have to turn around and used one of the kiosks to complete payment and receive activated room keys. The kiosk had no problem with our USA based VISA.The elevators are reasonably large, and require the keycard to call from the lobby. The only strange thing to note about the hotel is that while the lobby is inside, the atrium of each floor level is open to the sky, so the 'interior corridors' are really just outdoors. Did not particularly bother us as there were heaters in the hallway, but seemed a bit strange as it was 'raining' inside.The room we had was a 'Double'. It was not overly large, but was reasonably large enough for two people and a moderate amount of luggage. The bathroom was decent sized, but the tub was very difficult to step into due to the height of it, and the way the tub is designed let water flow all over the bathroom while showering. Amenities (comb, toothbrushes, cotton swabs, ect..) were very well stocked.Overall the room was pretty comfortable. The bed was nice, and sheets/pillows appeared high quality. I was most disappointed by the outlet placement/number. There was one outlet at the desk, one above the bed, one in the bathroom, and one for the air purifier (one plug at each outlet). I could have appreciated 1-2 more at the desk. I had seen the comments on AC/heat before staying at the hotel, and by mid-October it seemed like the AC had been turned off already. While it was still pretty warm in the room, leaving the window open (the 1-2" that it would move) made it very comfortable.
