review_body: Staff were very friendly from check-in throughout our 5 night stay, speaking enough English to assist us when needed. The room we stayed in was small but the value price we got on offer is perfect if you are going to be out all day anyway. Two of us could still fit in comfortably with a small double, a desk with chair, large tv, shower/toilet/bath ensuite and a large and a medium suitcase. Most importantly, the room was clean and the little well-thought-out touches made our stay really comfortable if you appreciate that sort of thing.They provide robes, slippers, shampoo, conditioner, body wash and an amazing array of other toiletries; toothbrushes/toothpaste, HAIR BANDS (lifesaver if you have long hair), razors with shaving cream, combs....these are replaced daily if you have used, along with fresh towels & robes.I think the bed sheets are changed every 3 days, although the bed is made everyday! Unfortunately, I was unwell on the 3rd day when this was meant to happen and spent most of the day in bed. The cleaner read the "do not disturb sign" and left fresh towels, robes and toiletries in a bag outside the door - so sweet! They were also lovely when you bumped into them in the mornings.The "public" baths in the basement are awesome! We waited until the second last day to try them even though it was in the back of our minds from the beginning that we wanted to give them go. I think we were a bit apprehensive at first being from London- we don't normally sit naked in a hot bath with a load of other naked strangers! Don't wait until the end to try because as someone else said below; it is absolutely perfect to do after a long day of being out and about in enormous Tokyo. It's so dim and steamy down there it's perfect for having a soak. Open-plan showering cubicles with a stool, mirror and toiletries are provided so that you can wash yourself beforehand.I can't comment on the hotel breakfast or food as we didn't have any. We preferred to go to coffee shops and get pastries for breakfast; saving our money to try some of the many amazing ramen places every evening.The hotel is near to two metro stations on either side of it and is situated within one of the busiest, liveliest districts in Tokyo where there is a lot happening. To get to the main Shinjuku trainmen (not the metro) it is a 15-20 minute walk. The hotel is also on one of the quiter roads within Shinjuku so that you can get some sleep (if you want to!).The hotel politely hold your luggage for you upon check-out (not sure for how long maximum, as we only needed an hour) which is a really kind gesture as although most hotels will do this, I have never seen every guest using this service before and the lobby was full of suitcases at 11am- they could have easily say no! Great customer service, thank you.I hope that one day I can come back to Japan and I would definitely stay at this APA again or try another branch because of this first experience. Shinjuku-Gyoenmae is a good starting point for daily adventures!

Although we were only here for 2 nights, it appeared to be a very nice, well kept hotel. Close to the train station and Shinjuku Gyoemmae park therefore well situated and we were able to get the rooms (3 doubles) for a good price.

Apa hotel shinjyuku Gyoenmae is a very pleasant place to stay. Once we got used (for european standards) very small room we enjoyed our stay very much. We could check in early, after a 20 hour travel, staff was very friendly and helpfull. Room was small, clean, very good shower and airco. In the neighbourhood plenty of restaurants. Subway 100 metres away.

Great location, close to the subway and train. Lots of things to see in the area. The rooms are really small, but comfortable. The staff is friendly. They have a nice public bath in the basement that is relaxing after a busy day of walking I had a pleasant stay and would stay again.

The hotel is at good location. Nice, clean and close to transport facilities - JR Shinjuku Train Station, as well as the different company subway lines. This made easy to get around Tokyo and other places of Japan. Plenty of food options near the hotel, with multiple 7-11 locations nearby with ATMs and breakfast options. I’d recommend this hotel to visitors that want to stay in the Shinjuku area. Room was well furnished but it was slightly smaller for my experience. I had to let my suitcase just on the bed. It was possible to store the luggage at the 24-hour front desk, while we had few hours free before we headed for the airport. You can watch the surroundings of this hostel in my videos in You Tube with title: 'Trip to Japan, George Bijay'.

I chose a Double bed room and it was tiny but clean. You only come here to shower, go for onsen and sleep. I chose this hotel because of the location. Near to the park, shopping, cafes, Y's Road store, nightlife. There's a supermarket nearby that sells cheap snacks and drinks. I also recommend trying out Osaka Ohsho nearby.

I stayed in this hotel for 5 nights and even if the room wasn't so big (actually i guess it's a normal size for the tokyo standards ) it was clean and confortable! The location was good and the price was excellent,if i'll go back to tokyo this will be my hotel again!

The hotel was right next to Shinjuku Gyoen National Gardens. We were relatively happy with the location, 10 minute walk to the JR Shinjuku line, okay for restaurants, and room was clean, fairly small and comfortable. We were on the 13 floor and had a view of the National Gardens (or the tops of the trees in the garden).

This was my second time staying at the APA hotel in the Shinjuku area of Tokyo. I chose to stay here again because i loved it so much the first time, plus thought that the location and price was great as well. The rooms are very small, thats not a secret for most Japanese hotels. This one is exceptionally small but don't really see it as a problem. Our suitcases fit just fine, I didn't bump my head on anything, and I had no problem relaxing. The size is adequate for what it is. Toiletries are great and are in great supply. The Tv is large and easy to swivel to your needs. The staff is always very helpful and professional. They don't go out of their way to make you coffee or anything, but thats not their job (as i read in a previous review for this hotel) We were given an "upgrade" for being a Gold member through Expedia, turns out it was a free can of soda and 2 coupons to eat in their restaurant. Hey, i'll take it. Free is free. I really don't have anything bad to say about this hotel and will definitely stay here again when I'm in tokyo.

There's not much a can add to what others have already said about the APA Shinjuku Gyoenmae. It's part of the Japanese APA chain, which is one of the largest chains in the country. The rooms are small and business oriented, so not good for a longer stay in Tokyo, but the good location near the Shinjukugyoen-Mae and Shinjuku Sanchome metro stations.The reception staff were polite and professional, but not interested in helping beyond their job. We asked them whether they could phone the mountain hut we'd reserved at Mount Fuji with an enquiry, as we couldn't speak Japanese, but the desk staff simply told us there's a phone in our room and to call ourselves. To be fair, they were quite busy checking in guests.We didn't have breakfast at the hotel, but like everywhere in Tokyo, there's plenty of 7-11 and Familymart stores to get some pastries, snacks and coffee in the morning. The gay district of Ni-Chome is opposite the hotel so there's plenty of interesting nightlife, as well as beef bowl chain restaurants (like Yoshinoya and Matsuya) and places to eat which are open late.Amongst others, we found a good, well priced, authentic izakaya (Japanese style pub) called Chikuzen-Ya literally across the road from the hotel. Although there isn't any English signage outside the izakaya, the staff spoke excellent English and they had English menus too.

This is a clean, accessible, and (very) cozy hotel in the heart of Shinjuku. The location cannot be beat, as it's just a 10-15 minute walk from the West Exit of the Shinjuku station and close to a ton of bars and restaurants. The hotel staff is very friendly and the amenities are solid, but the rooms are micro-sized. If you have 2 adults and 2 large suitcases, you're going to have to do some gymnastics to get around that room. That being said, it's worth it because you're right in the middle of the action.

Yes, do you want to visit a hotel with amazing location? Yes its APA Shinjuku-Gyoenmae. 500m to National Park, 750m to Shinjuku Station. Also its on the main road. Just some negative things, rooms are too small and you cannot find a place easily to put your suitcases.

Before I start, I would like to clarify that hotels in Japan do have rooms that are smaller than in the UK and USA so you need to have a bit of context there. The room was smaller than we're used to but still perfectly good. The bed was very comfy and the bathroom had a shower and bath. There were also some fab necessities included such as very decent shampoo, conditioner, body wash, tooth brush, toothpaste, razors, ear buds etc.The location is very close to the heart of Shinjuku but you will have a good 15 min walk to the station.The staff were very friendly and helpful and the onsen (public bath) was beautiful. That said, you can't go in with visible tattoos but, again, that is standard for Japan. Thank you all so much, We would definitely stay again.

the hotel was welcoming if rather official - the room was small but this is to be expected. it was very clean & had a good shower which is lovely after a day of sightseeing. the problem was storage - apart from 2 hanging pegs there was nothing else & as floor space is limited we did rather trip over our rucksacs - however the benefits outweighed the negatives :-)

The hotel is located in walking distance from Shinjuku station which will enable to zoom around Tokyo, and also very close to the beautiful gardens. In the basement there is a nice public bath where you can sooth your sore legs after busy days around Tokyo. The only thing I would complain about are really small rooms, so it is even hard to open your suitcases, in a double room. In Japan you do not have to mention that everything is clean and the staff is extremely helpful. Otherwise very good package for the price you pay.

At about $100 USD per night it's a decent value and extremely well located in Shinjuku, within a short distance to the subway and about a 10-25 minute walk to Shinjuku station. Typically small rooms that are well-kept and clean. Just don't bother with the breakfast: it's simply not worth $1,600 JPY ($14 USD), and only available until 9:30am. Poor quality food, limited menu. Instead go next door to Freshness Burger and try the Bacon & omelette burger - quite tasty for $410 JPY. The hotel does have an onsen bath on B1 and it's excellent after a day of walking around. I'd come back again.

My friend and i stayed here in our 3 nights in Tokyo. Prior to arriving I've already prepared my mindset that the hotel was going to be small but it was super small. I was with my friend and we share the bed that was bigger than a single but smaller than a double (luckily we're skinny) however, we wouldn't of lasted for a week. It'll be good for travellers who don't intend on staying in their hotel for more than a hour a day. Hotel staff were friends, check in was easy and the hotel room itself was super clean.

Basic but well kept hotel close to Shinjuku station and central Shinjuku area. It is also very close to Gyoenmae park which is very nice.Price is reasonable but of course it is japanese standard; room and beds are very small.

For the price I paid I think this is a very value for money stay. The room is standard Japanese size so I wouldn't complain. Is nice there is onsen in basement to use but it is quite crowded and busy.

Last minute with Expedia, if you book via Expedia, it could even give you extra 2 hours prior to checking time, in general, it was a really good stay. nice front desk with good English speaking instruction and the location is super continent, it takes me only 10 mins to JR Shinjuku station and only like 2 mins to metro Shinjyuku Gyoenmae station. Although I really wanna give out 5 stars to this hotel, but I feel like the room is a bit too small for my big body, I understand this is like normal thing in Tokyo, but if you are seeking for a big space hotel, you might have to think twice tho. regarding to the bath in the B1, its clean and the hot spring is quite big, avoid the rush hour, you could easily enjoy the bath facility all by yourself.

We stayed 4 nights here. This hotel is 1 min away from Marunouchi line station. Rooms are super small but we were ready for that. We came only with carry-ons and that was not a big deal. The room itself was sparkling clean and the houskeeping seems to be excellent! Hotel has spa which also was clean and very much enjoyable. We havent try hotel restaurant, but around the hotel numerous small places to eat, try them. Many times they dont speak much english just point at picture of the food you want. Hotel personel seems friendly and helpful. Unfortunatelly English is not a strong side of the front desk, they do speak some but seems they cant understand well when you speak.  I only had couple things I was upset with. First thing is that front desk girl refused to take prepaid letter and kept sending me to walk to the post office despite I explained that letter is paid. Well, maybe its a custom there. The other thing was that the houskeeping didnt refill tea in the room and I asked for it at the front desk. They didn't give me any and didn't send anyone to me, but the worst thing was that they were keep talking about me and my tea when I was leaving the lobby. That was the way too much, you dont talk about guests with your coleagues especially loud. Very unprofeccional! Overall the expirience with the hotel was not good. Its clean, quite and safe. You can walk to Shinjuku. Seems like no crime even at night. I'm not sure if I would stay there again or recommend it to the friend. Hopefully the service improves and this will be the excellent hotel because it has a potential.

We came to Japan for honeymoon and knew it was going to be all about the places, and not the hotels. We booked the APA as it was a great price, great location and looked smart. As with a lot of the hotels in Tokyo, the room was small. But we had a double bed, a fridge, kettle, big TV, and most importantly it was very clean and well kept.The location is excellent. A short walk to Shinjuku station and all that Shinjuku has to offer! With the underground just down the road so super easy to get anywhere in Tokyo. Also, the breakfast was really good as well!

Great location near major subways and of course easy walk to all the things to see in shinjuku including the park (1 minute) 10 mins to Shibuya and numerous restaurants and shops. shinjuku station is nearby as well as well as shinjuku sanchome (make sure you take the right exit when you return!).Only downside besides the small rooms (this is tokyo! they also have everything you need anyway) is that the area directly north seems to be a gay village of some sort so if that bothers you alot...at night you will see guys in dresses hanging out...then you may want to choose somewhere else!I did not try the restaurant in the hotel but it is 24 hrs i believe and they have laundry facilities (coin) and also a onsen in the basement!The bath is segregated and also has a 'outdoor' bath just in case it is too hot (like when you visit in the summer!).Great stay and great place for exploring tokyo.

We recently spent two nights at the APA to finish our three weeks in Japan.The location of the hotel was very good, convenient to lots of shopping and G nightlife and clubs.The hotel had a nice, clean onsite Onsen that was a nice way to end your day.The staff were very friendly providing lots of advice and directions to local attractions.The downside was the room was small but I guess consistent with Japanese standards. The bathroom was extremely small to the extent you had to leave the bathroom to dry yourself after a shower unless you stood in the shower recess.I would stay at this hotel again.

This hotel is walking distance to Shinjuku Gardens. It's about 15 minute walk to the Shinjuku train station. It's a quiet area and I have no complaints about its location.Unfortunately, the room is tiny. The window is tiny. The bathroom is also tiny. I would not recommend their twin bed accommodation for 2 people. I travelled with my teenage son and it was too claustrophobic for both of us. There is also a wet towel smell in the bedroom which hits you every time you get in. You get used to it after a while. The a/c is quiet enough. The bed is not comfortable. It's too hard. The pillow is horrible. It's tiny. The cover is tiny. This place is for small people. I would not stay here again.

This hotel is logistical the best hotel in Tokyo. It close to the train-hub in Tokyo and all central lines.In its neighborhood you'll find ample choice for dinner and lunch.The hotel has a fantastic spa - for free. Cleaning is very good. They have a good restaurant - so good that even people working in the neighborhood goes there.

Hotels in Tokyo can be really expensive and the ones in an area like Shinjuku are no exception. But we found this chain of budgethotels, which was a pleasant surprise. The location is absolutely perfect, on a main street and close to all bars, restaurants and shopping. Check in was smooth and staff did a good jobb at welcoming guests, although not as serviceminded as staff at other places in Tokyo. Rooms are very small, which goes for most hotels in this city. But its perfectly clean, has a modern and beds are very comfortable.We would hot hesitate about staying here again

I've stayed in Tokyo few months ago and they offered bigger rooms. The rooms are way too small. My aunt who booked a room for single person had an equal if not bigger room than ours. The front desk was sarcastic at times. It was near a lot of restaurants and it's around 5-7 minutes away from the train.

clean hotel,free wifi,near Tokyo Metro (M10-Shinjuku Gyoemmae)... 5 minutes walk to Hotel...near seveneleven, family mart, 100yen store, SERIA store (100yen store), yoshinoya.the bad thing was the bed.the bed was not flat and i think they have to change the position of the bed. i lived in the small double bed rooms, it suited for 2 persons only.the bed size was 140cm..

It only took me about 12 hours to acclimate to the small room and I considered it just one more great travel experience especially given the prices in Tokyo! The hotel is new and very clean. Staff were very efficient and polite. Bed was comfortable and the AC and free wifi worked effectively. The location is incredible if you like to explore. There is a subway entrance right around the corner and plenty of restaurants and coffee options. The Shinjuku Gyon Park is a must see. And you are only a couple of stations away from the Shinjuku station which is a main transportation hub. If arriving at Narita use the Express Train and save $$$. There are a couple of 7-11s and Family Marts to stock up your mini fridge. ATMs are at the 7-11s. Easy to hail a cab if you want one - do NOT bother with Uber in Tokyo. Area is very safe snd very quiet One of the perks of travel is to experience something different. This APA hotel delivers a quirky living experience at ax extraordinary price. Would stay here again

very good location ,just take 10-15 mins walk from Main JR station.But far away from the crowd in Shinjyuku.They can keep your luggage before your check in/out without any charges.Check in counter always busy ,but you can use auto check in machine.If raining day ,they will prepare umbrella for you ,you can get it from Front desk.

Think of this "hotel" as a capsule hotel that has a private bathroom, then your expectation will be set right. There is no public seating areas to relax in the hotel, it is just a bed and shower. The good:The hotel is clean and the room rate is reasonable.The public baths are nice.The location is very good.The bad:The rooms are so so small! I was prepared for a small room but this was tiny. Our luggage had to be moved each time we wanted to exit the room. The pillows provided were as thin as 4 sheets of A4 paper. If you have two big bags you will struggle for more than one night. Other than that it was good enough, we spent most of our time exploring Tokyo and not at the hotel.

Very happy with this accommodation, friendly staff, very comfortable bed. Nice room with good bathroom. Room is small but would not expect bigger for the location. And so close to everything. Would recommend to anyone.

The available rooms here are absolutely ideal for someone on a short stay business trip. Although unfortunately I was on a two week holiday, not a business trip which leaves you somewhat trapped in a miniscule room with 4 coat hangers and no storage space for suitcases, t-shirts, underwear etc. Despite the cramped conditions the room was spotless, the staff were friendly and helpful beyond their job role. It's a lovely hotel but I really can't advise staying there for more than 4 or 5 days as it just becomes a tad too cramped. My main upset came from the fact that I booked the hotel based on the fact that it has a traditional onsen and unlike almost every other hotel in the city it doesn't say 'no tattoos' on the website so I was really excited until I arrived at the hotel and was presented with a 'no tattoos' slip of paper. Sad times.

APA Hotel Shinjuku Gyouemmae is a typical Japanese business hotel - clean, provides the basic amenities and meals. It's also very well-located - there are cafes and restaurants nearby if you don't want to use the hotel facilities, and a minute's walk from the Tokyo Metro (Marunouchi line). The park is also just behind the hotel, and it's a great place to wind down from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. Do note that as this is not a luxury hotel - the rooms are VERY small and hence the hotel is better suited for travellers with no children. There's barely room to keep one big suitcase on hand. The hotel also has a particular quirk of requiring that all services be paid upfront - no charges to the room are accepted. You pay for your stay in full immediately on arrival. I did not purchase a meal ticket with my stay and was obliged to pay for my breakfast prior to having my meal, as the restaurant would not charge the meal to my room. This was unsettling, and a few fellow travellers were rather dismayed at this policy.Stay here if you are a single traveller who does not need a lot of perks and extra services - the location and other food choices around the hotel more than compensates. It's also easy enough to get to the airport - taxis are available to bring you to the Shinjuku Expressway Bus Terminal, and vice versa. However, if you have children, you may wish to reconsider. This is completely unrelated to the services provided by the hotel, but pls note that the owner of the APA chain has been embroiled in political controversies before (it is easy enough to google). If you feel strongly about such issues, this may not be the hotel for you either.

Stay here when writing this review.As most of the hotel in Japan with less than 4 stars hotel, the room is very small.The bed still using spring bed, the pillow is very thin. The bathroom is very small, portable bathroom I think :) The great thing about this hotel is clean, the onsen also great it open until 1 AM, the hotel close to Shinjuku-Gyoemmae Station only 5 minutes walk, convenience store also nearby.The breakfast was ok nothing special.The hotel provide luggage storage for few days as long as you will check in back again, they will check your reservation to confirm that.The hotel also provide airport transfer to Narita Airpot for JPY3,000/person.

I booked a room for 3 people including a kid, when we checked in we were not being accommodated and ended up booking another room. Check in counter people are very rude and the lady who check us in has big time attitude in spite that she can not communicate and understand simple English. The rooms are very small (very typical), thank goodness we only stayed for 2 nights but it was a disaster, as what my daughter describe the experience. I will NOT recommend and will NOT stay at APA Hotel EVER again!!!!

Do not stay here. The rooms are miniscule with no room to put suitcases down. There is no wardrobe- just 4 hangers!! The staff were unhelpful and blanked us. We tried to talk to the manager but funnily enough, always not available. We travelled all over Japan and had no problems except here. It's not cheap either!

The hotel is very clean, large and good location at Shinjuku area.As usual for the standard hotel, the room is small with double bed but it is enough to put your luggages free of moving in the room especially at the room's aisle.The location is close to Shinjuku train station, many markets, cafes and restaurant in surrounding area.Good hotel for holiday and stay at Shinjuku area. There is halal shinjuku ramen close to the hotel, very interesting for muslim to get the halal food close to the hotel.

Like most of Japan, rooms are small. Clean, efficient, no- nonsense. Good location, excellent variety for breakfast and overall good value. Very busy, but quiet.Great location for subway access, and a short walk to the mega Shinjuku station area.

This hotel is in a very good position to visit Tokyo. It's part of the Shinjuku area, minutes of walking also from the Kabukicho area (which is very good for dinner and evening activities in general) and right behind the Gyoen park.It's a 10-15 minutes walk from the main Shinjuku station, but in a few minutes you can get to Shinjuku-Sanchome station which gives you access to the Maronuchi, Shinjuku and Fukutoshin lines.We booked online with an offer so the price was very fair and honest, also because what you get is the very typical cramped business hotel with rooms with space enough for one but not to open even a single large bag (let alone two).Staff at the hotel has been helpful, although sometimes English can become a barrier for more detailed requests, as they assisted us to send our luggage from Tokyo to Kyoto via Takkyubin service.Overall it's very good value for the price you pay.

Last minute booking via agoda.com The place was very close to Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden. (walking distance). There's a lot of restaurants nearby. Shunjuku station can also be reached by foot. We booked the standard room which is a bit tiny. Not doable if you have big luggage with you. The room has all the essentials you need. Even the small bathroom has a bathtub in it. ( which is very common in any japanese hotel) . We really has a comfy sleep in their bed. You can found a public bath inside the hotel (onsen) but I wasn't able to try it. There is also a restaurant in the lobby.In general, we had a great stay in this chain of hotel and will definitely recommend the place to those planning to visit Tokyo.You can also leave your luggage upon check out for free. They will give you a tag and just surrender it upon claiming your bags.

Check in was strange, maybe standard for this chain, but once you talk to the person on the desk (who was friendly) they give you a room key, you then proceed to a Kiosk to actually perform check-in etc. There was a person on hand to help with this, so it went pretty smoothly.The room itself was tiny, with a tiny bathroom, a very high step over required for the shower, fine but could cause an issue for some.Basically 1 or 2 feet of floor around the bed, so it was cramped, but had all the expected facilities and toiletries ( actually more than expected).The location is great, beside the Shinjyuku gardens, few steps from a metro.It is also very close to two sorts of areas, one with shopping, bars etc. and another couple of blocks packed with all sorts of restaurants and bars.This may not be for you as a tourist though, as you will recieve no help with tours, booking etc. from the front desk, which is a shame, but there are many online resources these days so we were fine.

The hotel is fine, it is 2 minutes walking to subway station Shinjuku gyoenmae which is very convenient (not a JR station). The facilities in the hotel are good. The bathroom is very small tough. The double bed is very small and fits two normal people, who should mind sleeping very close to each other. Two big people cannot sleep in this bed. The bed was ok, however the pillows are horrible (very very very low). We slept on the 14th floor, it was very hot in this room. But there is AC. The room is cleaned everyday. Didn’t use the breakfast or SPA service. Please note: the room is 11m2 so if you are with 2 people and you have a double / small double room and 2 suitcases there is almost no room left to move around. For 1 or 2 days this is fine, however we slept here for 4 nights, this is not very comfortable. Wifi in the rooms is very goodThe receptionists don’t speak any English so asking for tips / transport options is not very good. Location is very good, walking to shinjuku station is only around 7-9 minutes.

We needed a room for a few nights in Tokyo and selected the Shinjyuku Gyoenmae. The location is great, with subway and restaurants very close. The facilities were good as well, in that everything worked. The bathroom was unique, in that you had to step up into it (mind the sill on the shins!) and it was very functional and clean. But the room was tiny. We had three pieces of luggage and there was no room for any of it. It was just a short hallway, a counter and a bed. Whoever came up with the joke "the room was so small you have to leave to change your mind" was thinking about this place.All of that was acceptable, as small rooms are normal in Japan but for us the greater issue was the front desk staff. The check in was bizarre and the check out was bordering on rude. Maybe it was a communication issue, but I was taken back by the dismissive manner of the staff. The final blow was the 400 yen charge to call a taxi. Maybe that is normal in Japan, and if so, then it should have been explained clearly. In the end, we walked out and found our own ride. For this first experience in Japan, customer service was the downfall.On a positive note, the attached restaurant was wonderful and reasonably priced for dinner.

Good for location and travel in the city. There is subway near hotel, convenience store open 24/7 near hotel and many restaurants around the area. The hotel room itself is typical Tokyo size, which is small and no enough space to open your huge luggage. Bathroom is small but there is bathtub that fit you! Air-condition and heater available plus air-purifier. Breakfast is good. What I like about this place is Onsen!

Like most places in Tokyo, the APA was a bit smaller than what we are used to but still an excellent choice. Very clean, staff were friendly, location is close to Shinjyuku station but not too close..

nice position in Shinjyuku and very close to Shinjyuku Gyoenmmae Park if you visit in april for the cherry blossom. 10 minutes walk from Shinjyuku subway. For the rest the rooms are tiny,no space to place your things. My laggage was rest against the wall behind the door and for some reason felt down...couldn't open the door to re-enter ...Personal friendly and willing to help.

This was the first stop for my husband and I on our honeymoon. We stayed four nights here and were generally happy with the place. The rooms are modern, clean, and ... not that small. I mean, sure they're small, especially in comparison to rooms in most Western countries, but reading other reviews I was terrified our married life would begin with us living on top of each other without space to move around or get dressed. I will add the caveat that we were upgraded from a small double room to a double room, but we had room to lay both of our suitcases down and still move around the room. Location is great, just across the road from Shinjuku gyoen park, 10 minutes walk from Shinjuku station, and Shinjuku gyoen subway station just across the road. The public onsen is nice, modern and clean, although there isn't a huge amount of room.

The hotel is in a great location, close to Shinjuku station. The thing with this place, though, is that the rooms are tiny! You can't even have a suitcase open and expect to move around the room. The beds might be 'double' beds in Japan but I doubt they would qualify as that in any other country! The shower cannot be used without soaking the entire bathroom. Using it hand held is the only way. Another issue is that there are not enough lifts to service the number of rooms. Expect to wait a while to get to where you want to go. Overall, it's somewhere to lay your head but, for the price paid, you'd expect more.

The reception staff are very accommodating, the rooms are clean, basic toiletries were provided and with good Wi-Fi connection. The hotel is a 10-minute walk to the famous Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden where one can enjoy Cherry Blossoms (Sakura) viewing. There are many restaurants around the hotel and it is a walking distance to a few train stations.The hotel is at least a 20-minute walk to the Shinjuku station but not feasible for walking if one has a few pieces of luggage.Note:a. Luggage can be stored at the hotel for some time. We left the hotel for a few days to go to places outside Tokyo and we were allowed to leave our luggage until we have returned to the hotel for another 2 nights of stay.b. Umbrellas were available to hotel guests to use.The main issue is the hotel’s room size. Unfortunately, the room is significantly small even just for myself. There is no space to move around. It was more challenging for my brother and his family (2 adults and 1 child) who stayed in a room with the same size.

ChileUp
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: The room was very small and I mean small. There is barely enough space for 2 and luggage . Everything else worked though. The aircond is supposed to provide some warm heated air in cold temperatures but it provided cold air. The problem was mysteriously solved when I complained to the front desk manager. I said mysterious because she said there was nothing she could do about it. There must be something about speaking in English and with a Japanese mind. Let me give you an example. When you ask if the aircond works they will say "right now its not working". You then give a big stare and the person takes the remote control and turns the aircond on. Get my drift? Location was perfect i.e. right across the gyeonmae park and walking distance to the BIG Shinjuku station. Breakfast was just OK.

good hotel, a little more modern than its counterpart in Osaka. Rooms are small of course but thats japan. Location is good and on the doorstep of good restaurants and near the subway. A strange issue were the pillows....they were tiny flat things?!? anyway its the location that was most important

Stayed here one night prior to departing on a tour. Rooms are very small even by Japanese standards. Yes it was close to the station and there is the prospect of some nightlife in the nearby back streets if you have the time. Service is more like self serve as you do book in but outgoing you insert present your room card on a screen opposite the check in desk. No chance for that personal touch and doesn't really speed up departure as no one seems to know the procedure anyway. Their breakfast if included does give you more western options than the average and we also received a free drink so this brought the cost down.

Location was excellent but that's about all I can say positive about it. Rooms were so small , it felt like a cave. Low ceilings made it even more so. There was a tiny window but the curtain had to be kept closed as it backed onto another window. It was clean though. Carpet was wet from previous guests as water from bathroom ran down onto the lower level of the cave. Pillows tiny slabs of some uncomfortable stuff. Room for a bed, thats all, so sleep and wash there and quickly get out. Would not recommend.

Compared to all the other hotels I've stayed in in Japan this was the worst value for money. Location is good but the room was so small we couldn't unpack and had to keep everything in our cases or tread on it. Pillows were so thin we got neck ache. Felt like we'd accidentally booked a capsule hotel

As my mum wanted to be as close as possible to Sakura, the hotel is well located near to Shinjuku Park that is less than 5 mins walk away. And hotel is close to Shinjuku where the hub of activities are going on.Check in was very regimental in the view as the receptionist keep insisting that we come back at 1 pm and do the registration. She did it in very stern looking style which is very uncommon in my experiences in Japan. The room which I eventually checked into gave no space other than 1 single luggage and less than 10 steps of walking space in the room! Definitely one of the smallest room in Japan I have been toLocation as I mentioned stood out as it was less than 3 mins walk to entrance of subway and with many restaurants nearby. We didn't chose the breakfast package which is a right move as there are at least 3 places for breakfast less than 2 mins away! Good quality too.What puts me off is during check out, we asked for a cab to take us to train station and the staff simply said you can just go flag one down from the street, very unprofessional.Overall a good experience other than the room size and service attitude. Depends on what one needs , I would still consider if the price is cheaper.

The room was extremely small and could barely fit two people with luggage. Everything was clean and worked fine nonetheless. We travelled during the high season (cherry blossom time), so the room price was quite expensive considering what we got, but this is Tokio. The best part of the hotel is its extremely convenient location near Shinjuku station and several metro lines. It is also in close walking distance to Shinjuku restaurants.

I've stayed at APA hotels a number of times. APA Shinjuku Gyoenmae property is convenient to the the east side of Shinjuku station. Be aware there are three APA properties on the east side of Shinjuku station.

Being an airline worker constantly travelling I look for clean efficient places to stay with convenient proximity to travel hubs, 24hr food supply, short wait times for what I want, nature and relative quiet. Even though APA is in a direct 2/3 lane main road into Shinjuku the area is quiet. We're from Port Melbourne Australia so we know about noise. Apa's quite new, clean, quiet hotel 20 meters from one of Tokyos major BEAUTIFUL parks, 900mts from Shinjuku main railway station / Shopping district with 24/7 Family Mart and 7/11 convenience stores 20mts away i and my partner vote it 11/10. In all sincerity we had an XL double bed room with a small desk counter and squishy but usable bathroom but it was all spotless and upto date stylish. 14 floors with 3 lifts so you're not waiting long. Express check out i falls you have to do is drop electronic swipe tags off. There's a vending machine on each level but it's not a tacky aspect of the hotel. A soft drink is around 120yen and a Kirin beer approx 180yen. Thanks APA. The most loveliest of staff. We'll be back later in the year to explore more of the region. Oh oh. Add the breakfast option. Worth it. Quiet and tasty. And the onsen spa in B1 with easy to understand rules. We spent 3 days exploring upto a 3km radius from the hotel by foot then trained it down to Tokyo city Dover Gardens Shopping complex area. Hope this helps.

Clean and cheap but extremely small. However, as this is tokyo you would expect it. This hotel is very close to the 3 chome train line and direct to Ginza and fish market so that was really good. It is also within walking distance of shinjuku main shopping. The goyza restaurant opposite the hotel was really delicious. It also has a public bath, and can be used by the hotel guest for free. Quite good, if you didn't want to shower in the small bathroom or you wanted to soak your calves from all that walking around. Overall, a good budget hotel with no frills but clean.

Great top sushi place opposite, in walking distance of main Shinjuku attractions.Room was small but clean. No great view. Walking distance to all the small bars and Robot Restaurant and nightlife. Blackhole nice restaurant to go too.

I stayed at the APA hotel for the first time. The rooms are smaller than usual (even in Tokyo). The convenient location makes up for the lack of space. It is a couple minutes walk to the train station with lots of places to eat near byIt is also close to Shinjuku (within walking distance).

As with many hotels in Tokyo the rooms are small. Wish two people and luggage you need to think logistically to get packed. I would recommend this hotel. Comfortable bed but had to ask for additional pillows. Rooms are clean and modern. The spa in the basement is excellent.

Their location is very good - within 15 minutes walking distance to the busy centre of Shinjuku and only 3 minutes to the train station. The rooms are smaller than other Japanese hotels that I've stayed in though. They have a spa which I didn't have time to go to.

The best thing about this hotel is the location. Close to the main shopping trip and subway stations- Shinjuku Gyonomae is a short walk from the hotel. There is a 7/11 store nearby which is convenient. The rooms are exceptionally small! No room to lay down your suitcases or unpack. If you are planning on going out and sightseeing then it should be fine however if you are the type to spend time in the hotel just keep in mind the size and how claustrophobic it can be. The hotel staff were friendly and always tried to help with giving us information and directions. Some of them had limited English but overall it was still ok. There is a restaurant at the bottom floor which is where you can have breakfast if you choose as part of your accommodation stay/deal. We didn't go here for breakfast however did stop in for a drink at happy hour.

The hotel is modern clean and functional. The spa seemed popular but I didn't use it. It's stylish clean with shops, restaurants and the big park very close. The rooms are small but this was not a problem - I only used the room to sleep. Good value.

We stayed at this hotel for 8 nights and absolutely loved it. We were within 2 minutes region of a mini supermarket, subway and food places. The subway is literally around the corner its m10 stop exit 1 we got three amazing coffee shops at our doorstep and a subway and only 10min walk into central Shinjuku which is excellent for shopping restaurant and the atmosphere plus we were lucky enough to find godzilla The hotel itself is very clean, friendly staff, rooms are small but this is common for japan.I would definitely stay here againMy only negative points are that the spa was just disappointing it was actualy just a bath and they didnt offer any treatments and because we have tattoos we weren't allowed to use this facility. Also the building itself is quite small so you dont get much of a view

Inside the hotel, it is very cold, just as cold as outside!Even in the room, it was very cold since the airconditioning goes off when the guests are not in the room.There was no window in my room.Unfortunately I happend to fall to the door to the bathroom which broke down so easily. Fortunately, it was plastic and I was not hurt. It would have been the different if it was glass.The APA Hotel asked compensation for 25.920 yen for the repair.Never more APA Hotel for my part.

My first trip to Japan. The hotel was perfectly adequate for our four nights in Tokyo. Clean and tidy. I'd recommend a twin bedroom which is much more spacious than a double. We found the double room a bit cramped. Good size onsen (not that I have much experience!) . Good variety of Japanese breakfast options, with fewer Western options for the unadventurous tourist! Subway was just around the corner, so very handy. Staff not particularly friendly, but I suppose that is all one can expect in a bigger hotel. A second pillow in the bed would have been good. Nice to have BBC tv option. Located a 10 minute walk from the hubbub of Shinjuku, which suited us just fine.

I was happy with how clean the hotel and room was. Yes, it is small. My husband and I shared a "full" size bed. It was a little tight and would not be able to fit more than 2 people. We had a nice view of the park. It was a comfortable bed. The pillows were flat but I folded mine in half for more support. We cannot speak or read Japanese so some things were hard to navigate, i.e. the heat-A/C. We called down to the desk and they were able to adjust our temperature without even coming to the room. We did not dine in their restaurant. There are plenty of places to eat around for a better price. The staff was friendly but appeared to only speak very little English. I think the hotel is in a great location to attractions and food. I would stay here again.

Great location. Walking distance from shopping strips and really good restaurants. Lots of convenience stores close by, and also really good access to the subway. Rooms are very small, however it was very well appointed and had everything you could need while on holiday, plus we were hardly in our room it didn't really matter.

Great location. Was fairly easy to get to from the airport via airport limousine bus to Shinjuku station then 700yen taxi to hotel. There is a closer station (Shinjuku Gyoenmae) which you can take if you transit through Tokyo station. Close to main part of Shinjuku where major department stores are and about 10 min walk to Shinjuku station. Lots of Family Marts and 711 stores close by to pick up reasonably priced snacks/meals when too tired to go out (esp with kids!). Rooms were small but to be expected. Beds very comfortable. Only downside was limited space for luggage in room. The big plus though was the Onsen/spa on the bottom floor of the hotel. Was really appreciated after a long day sightseeing! We didn't try the restaurant in the hotel so can't comment on that. There was a great Yakitori restaurant though only about 20m from hotel (turn left after exiting hotel) I have not idea what the name is! Also a good supermarket closeby for fresh fruit etc and a cute little 100 yen shop across the street.

We stayed here after an Airbnb disaster. The hotel was great, clean and the staff very friendly. They kept our bags safe while we made an overnight trip to Kyoto. We stayed here a total of 3nights. It's close enough to Shinjuku shopping area, and far enough from the hustle and bustle. The rooms are small, but that is standard In Tokyo. They have everything you need tucked away nicely in the purist Japanese maximising space way. The bathroom is good and has a deep soak tub, but it's kind of small. Shower is also great. To get to the hotel use Shinjuku Sanchome station 2mins walk. The hotel is on the opposite side of the road, right hand side as you exit. Use exit 3, This particular exit has lift access, perfect for when you have suitcases. The hotel also boasts a public bath in the basement. Didn't get time to check it out, but there were several people in the lift that you could see had used it. You must try the 'Te Raume' restaurant which is a short walk away for amazing authentic Okonomiyaki and the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden which is on the parallel street behind the hotel.

About a 10 minute walk from Shinjuku station and well placed for restaurants and other sites. The room was very small (however that's what you get in Tokyo) but had everything you needed. Clean and comfortable. Friendly staff. Restaurant was very overpriced but there are plenty of great local ones near by. Would recommend!

Good place to live for some few days.central so it's not far to walk,to the most turist attraction in the neighborhood.the hotel rooms in them self it's small but practical.and a friendly staff but not so good to speak English but that is general in Japan.The breakfast was noting to speak of I think not in my taste I will say.anyway I will comeback for sure if I will wisit Shinjuku again.

The room was very clean but extremely small. We were two adults and there was not enough space to put our two open suitcases. Nice bathroom amenities provided. Quite a distance to walk to Shinjuku JR station, but next metro station is only 100m away.

Got this hotel due to a desperate need resulting from flight cancellation to Sapporo. Rooms are clean but extremely small. The room is DECENT in my opinion despite the small size. What pisses me off is we had two rooms and decided to give up one and move luggages to the remaining room and paid extended charges for one. When we returned they forbid 4 of us to go up the lift to the single room despite us saying we were just taking luggages. No need to even ask for use of toilets as they sent a guy up with us to supervise we actually do not go into the room. Felt uneasy and prison like ..First and last time for APA ...

Great hotel, not that close to the JR station but still within walking distance of Shinjuku JR. Metro is very close. Small room as expected for Tokyo but had everything you need and very clean. Couldn't fault it at all.

The room was too small, it's hard to put a suitcase and away from shinjuku station, the food is quite tasty. Tourists better looking for hotels near shinjuku station. Not recommended for Families with kids.

Stayed here December 15, Jan 16, Mar and May 16 The place is great location, rooms comfy, breakfast lovely, Room Coffee and Tea :) Nice Bath Tub and Bathroom, Will stay again in December 16Staff are great all around,

Stayed in single room for one night, the price is very reasonable but the room is super tiny. The bed is comfy, room is clean, bathroom is very small. The thermostat doesnt really work as it only gives out heat, no air conditioning in the room. End up I turned it off and open the window. Location is central enough but still quite a walk to JR Shinjuku station or Kabukicho area.

Property was in a great location, nearby shops, food, park, transit, coffee etc. Room was very small! The bed was against the wall, so one person had to climb over the other to get out...Yikes. Would be ideal for solo traveler. Good value.The onsen was great and popular with guests, I understand that onsen is hard to in downtown Tokyo (but it's just a group bath). Didn't try the outdoor tub at the bottom of the light shaft, nor did we try the onsite restaurant, but at least it was there. If you can, avoid the basement laundry!! Washers worked great, but the dryer took HOURS!! Dryers didn't work so well. Also avoid the trouser presses, another a lost cause. Front desk Staff were GREAT! Spoke English which was so helpful. Also they gave out free umbrellas in the rain, awesome!

The room was clean, with all the amenities, except space. Fine if you are out and about all day. Was the smallest room we stayed in during our 18 days in Japan. Only room for 1 case. But you don't stay here to just stay in the room. Only about a 10 min walk to Shinjuku station. Public Baths downstairs. About a 15 min walk to Tokyo Metropolitan Government building to get a view from the 43rd floor for free. If its clear you can see Fuji San

Chose this accommodation for my first nights in Tokyo. I stayed for three weeks in Japan and flew in through Tokyo. It's not easy behind your computer back home to pick a place in a metropole like Tokyo is. This hotel was an excellent choice. It is close to Shinjuku station, which is one of Tokyo's busiest stations with 3 million passengers each day. The NEX (Narita Airline Express) runs to this station. If you've exchanged your JPR at Narita Airport you can use your JPR. I activated my JPR after my five nights in Tokyo and paid about 3000Y for this fair. There are cheaper options but this is a comfortable direct option which is convenient after a long flight. It's a short walk to the hotel. Or change at the Subway to Shinjuku Gyoenmae Station, then it's just across the street. The hotel is right next to the Gyoenmae park which I can definitely recommend to visit. During my trip I found out the quality of APA hotels in Japan differ. I had some bad ones too unfortunately. This is one of the newer ones and is excellent. I was just by myself and had a single room. The rooms are smaller in Japan, so if you need your space or if you're a couple think about upgrading. The rooms have everything you need. There are many amenities and the general level of cleanliness in Japan is really good. Housekeeping service during my stay was flawless. I paid about 240€ for 3 nights, which is not bad for Tokyo rates. I picked this to relax the first nights after my stay. Walk around Shinjuku, you'll be amazed. Don't talk back to the guys who try to pull you into bars. Buy a suica or pasmo card and use Tokyos subway to get around.

Since this was my first time in Asia, it was also my first time at an APA hotel chain branch. I was pleasantly surprised by how luxurious it was. Yes, the room is small, as are almost all rooms in Tokyo, but once you adjust to that, it's quite a special experience. Each room has a flat screen TV with the sharpest picture I have ever seen on any hotel TV in my life and about a dozen channels. There is a desk, pairs of permanent as well as disposable slippers, bathrobes, coffee, tea, creamer, hair dryer, and a mini fridge. In addition, amenities are replaced daily: toothbrush, razor, hair brush, shower cap, q tips, body sponge, etc. The bathroom in the room has a built in bidet in the toilet with three different spray options and a range of water pressure choices as well. There are laundry machines in the basement, coin operated, and 24 hour lobby service and entrance. For security purposes, a key is required to operate the elevator as well as to enter the rooms but you can come and go 24/7. A free daily Japan Times newspaper is offered in the lobby. The biggest amenity, however, is the public baths in the basement, nudity required, with separate facilities for each gender, open to all guests each morning and night. The property is one block from a subway stop. The only negative I can cite is that although the web page listed late checkout as a "free amenity" provided in the cost of the room, the front desk insisted that was not true and pointed to a sign there which says late checkout costs 1,000 Japanese yen per hour (up to 3 hours maximum, or 2 PM). There was also a language barrier as the staff really does not speak English, but in my opinion it is not possible for worldwide hotel staff to speak every guest's language so I do not fault them for that. By the way an earlier post said that upon checking in each guest receives a free snack--that policy has been discontinued apparently, as the front desk advised me they no longer do that. Overall, housekeeping was excellent and staff was helpful, if a bit aloof at times. This hotel is a good choice and, in my opinion, a bargain for what they offer and for the convenient location.

We spend one night in Tokyo before going back home. The hotel is well located directly in one of the biggest and most popular districts of Tokyo : Shinjyku. Near : JR train station, restaurant, shops and many skyscrapers. Reasonable price and room was super clean.

A mate and I visited Tokyo and were looking for budget accommodation that was clean and in a safe & vibrant area. Look no further.Location: As good as it gets. Walking distance to the entertainment & shopping areas and a stones throw to beautiful open gardens.The subway is minutes away with the main Shinjuku JR rail line a 10-15 minute walk.Hotel: I don't travel to stay in hotel rooms. The rooms are "compact" (like all hotel rooms in Japan). If you like your space then you will have to spend some coin and go for double rooms.The rooms are very well layed out, clean, neat & tidy. They come with all the mod cons like aircon, coffee/kettle etc, tv, bath, shower, toilet, mini fridge, wifi, 240v western style power points, complimentary water and bathroom accessories like shampoos, conditioners, soap etc. Money changer is a 5 minutes walk.Staff:Couldn't fault them. Helpful & friendly.Price:Great mid-range value for money price range.Summary:Actually couldn't fault this hotel. Will definitely stay here again when returning and will recommend to anyone visiting Tokyo.

Location is great with easy access to public transport, bars and restaurants.I tried the breakfast buffet, which was very poor, admittedly I went near the end of breakfast service however it was cold and just left over remained. It was very expensive for what I gotThey only seem to have 1 clothes iron for the whole hotel. I asked a couple times to use it and was always told another guest had it and they would bring it to my room when available. The iron never came.Overall clean, tidy, great location and friendly enough staff

15 min walk from Shinjuku Station.Clean, modern hotel. Bottled water, robe and slippers in room as well as toiletries. Rooms are small but comfortable. Hotel has a spa. Separate areas for men and women. Main shopping area 5 min. walk. Many restaurants in the area. Very safe.

2 metro stops from shinjuku station, but is walkable if you travel light.. 10/15 minutes, the hotel is in a good position but far enough from the buzz of shinjuku h24 amusements.. The rooms are compact, in pure japanese/hk style but well designed! And furniture are good quality. The bed/pillow wasn't very comfy.It even has a portable bag support/bag stand. Plenty of hangers, dehumidifier, flat screen tv sat, a computer desk with chair, coffee/tea maker. Pleanty of power sockets but in jp standard, no adaptor provided.Fridge but No safe! You can fill your fridge with drinks from vending machine & the hotel has a self service laundry++The hotel has a particular attention @fire & offers some kind of fire protection gown that should you allow breath & escape in case of fire, but looks like plastic, i wonder if can sustain a fire. On the side of the bed there is a mini led torch that activates in case of removal. Full set of toiletries provided, wash/rinse toilet, the bathroom is the standard plastic box that you see in many hotels. The hotel offer an in house spa/onsen, no sauna or steam but 3 pools.. Is for guests only Mineral water is provided from the 2nd day only & only if you are a good boy & has not to change linens, like in every other APA hotel

Stayed for 5 nights in September. The hotel is perfectly located just outside of the heartland of Shinjuku, but within easy walking distance of everything there is to see and do in the area. Convenience stores and ATMs all nearby and Metro is down the street. Staff are efficient and professional and check-in and check-out was a breeze. Rooms are decent sized for Tokyo standards (read small). Do yourself a favor and book a double for a little extra space. While small, the rooms have al of the modern conveniences. Comfy bed, fridge, small desk, and excellent a/c. Wifi is free and signal was strong on the 11th floor. Complimentary bottle of water daily. For the price, I would recommend this property for anyone seeking a no frills option in Shinjuku. If coming from Haneda, its easy enough to take the airport Bus to Shinjuku Station, and then a cab for Y730 to the hotel. If you dont have a lot of luggage, its walkable in mu opinion.

Functional but rather bland hotel in Shinjuku. Not far from the shops a lively Gay area nearby. A great Gyoza restaurant right opposite is worth a visit and open till 6am. Small rooms but functional, spa downstairs is 2 hot pools and showers small but nice. Coin op washing machines if u need them too.

Although the rooms were tooo small my kids loved the hotel they thought it was cute.My self I felt like a giant loool.Clean room flat belows (I dont know why hhh) but you can request for a normal one.Excellent friendly check in. Instant check out which we loved it as we had to leave early morning.The spa was a plus. Location was great near by restaurants and shopping is not that far.

Great value, we paid ~$100/night, location is good, close to Shinjuku- all walkable and gardens. Quiet as well! Got a double room, is small like a singles university dorm room, double bed is tight (smaller then American size double), but 2 adults fit. The upside of the hotel is seems very new, modern, clean, good hot Asian baths in basement (free access), cheap coin laundry and close to everything. We'd definitely stay here again in Shinjuku! Close to subway too.

This is an amazing hotel with wonderful service for business traveller like me . It's located conveniently in shinjuku business district , all shopping area and wonderful restaurants. Most importantly nearby the train station . I also recommend for short trip travellers who wants to enjoy few days in Tokyo and love shopping . You will love it . Hotels known for the spa and quiet rooms . Check it out...

Seems like this is a local chain, I guess like the Holiday Inn. I choose this particular one as it is new and had an outdoor bath. I went to the main line station and it's quite a walk to the hotel, along a dull dual carriageway which made the walk even more painful. Suggest going to the subway station which begins with S and is the name of this hotel. That is right under the building.The check in was smooth though a bit odd, you check in with a real person and they give you a key card and you have to check in with a machine around the corner that gives you your room number. Room was small but clean and comfortable with high quality freebies. The comunal bath was very nice they even have these huge ceramic flower pots you can bath in. When they say outdoor bath it's pushing the boat out a bit yes it is out door but under all the Aircon and roof top plumbing equipment. As in you can't see anything if it rains you might get wet. I did not try the food so can't comment. What let's it down is the location there is nothing around it. A petrol station and two restaurants. The more interesting places are only a few stops away on the underground. I would stay again purely from the value point of view. A clean pleasant new hotel. I like the little touches like comics in the room.

All other hotels were either full or too expensive with last min booking so we ended up staying in this hotel. It was not that bad actually. They have everything you need and is conveniently located near train station. There is an onsen within the hotel that you can shower and use the facilities. The room is decent, a little small but ok. The pillow was too thin but you can request a thicker one from the housekeeper. The only drawback? The housekeeping lay down all their things outside your room during cleaning... Lol

Rooms are small but clean. Bed is averagely comfortable. Location is fantastic, located just a few minutes walk from the subway. This place has an in-house onsen which was very clean and nice. They are very strict with check-out 1 second late and you will need to pay extra.

We stayed for 2 nights at this hotel and it was ok, though they can improve their service. It's well located, but the rooms are extremely small even for Japan standards; my husband could hardly fit in it with our carry-on luggage. There was no space for anything else. They can also improve the cleaniness of the place because it was kind of dusty since the first day and remained that way.

We are reserved the room until July28 for 1 room, Double Bed.However, after checked-in we found that the size of the Bed was not corrected. Theyvare assign us to stay in the semi-double Bed , and the staff insisted that it was exactly the same that we book. this is unacceptable for us to stay in the room that they dowgrade us. Satit K.Note:1st pic, the room that we booked2nd &3rd pic, the room that they are assigned us to stay for this visit.

The price is fair so we booked in just three days before arrival. Room is small but it's very clean. We stayed in Shinjuku for three days, most of time we were outside shopping so we only spend very little time in the hotel. Good place for budget short trip. Staff also very friendly.

I think this hotel was very good value for the price. Very clean and comfortable room, and location, short distance to the subway, and a bit longer but good walk to the train station and the shopping and nightlife area of Shinjuku. There is also a free spa, although I didn't get to use it.

Nice location to stay, 3 minute walk to Shinjuku park, 1 minute to subway line and lots of good places to eat. Hotel is clean, everything you need in the room, only the rooms are just too small for average European guests. But good plce to sleep though.

Although the decor of the room was lovely, the bedroom is very small and cramped. I was only staying here for one night on this Japan tour and all I can say is 'Thank goodness'. The bed is quite a small double bed and there is not enough room for suitcases in the room. There is only 2 hooks and 4 hangers available for clothes attached to the wall mirror and no other space provided. Therefore, you would be living out of a suitcase on the floor here. The hotel have no irons available for guests which in my opinion is a necessity in any hotel around the world. There is 4 trouser presses available on each floor for guests to use but these are not convenient for anything other than trousers! Bathroom is very compact but clean. The hotel is situated in a decent location within a few mins walk from the main area of Shinjuku. Although the bedroom was disappointing, the onsen and spa area was very nice and surprisingly spacious. I went early evening and the onsen was empty so it was nice and peaceful. Hotel staff are very friendly and helpful at this hotel. I personally wouldn't stay here again and I would advise guests not to stay here for more than one night at most.

I am very satisfied with this hotel and it's no surprise since its part of the APA chain. Good size rooms with comfortable beds and bathroom. It's near the subway and it's within walking distance to the shopping areas and plenty of restaurants nearby.

Primarily this trip concerned photographing Sakura and buying a serious camera. Mostly the hotel functions excellently unless you expect lots of human iteraction. Rooms are "Tokyo size" but perfectly presented with comfortably crisp white sheets and the common "one piece" plastic bath toilet. The situation is perfect for the park, Shinjuku shopping, and (GB) across the road was celebrating it's 30th anniversary. They didn't remember me from 30 years ago. The LGBT scene across the road is more foreigner friendly than it was 30 years ago. Pity I'm not 30 years younger. Breakfast was very crowded and one assertive American "lady" took it upon herself to clear away my place setting as I was recharging my coffee cup as the place was running out of tables. There is easily available delicious food on the same street including a famous noodle bar.

review_body: stayed one night in our tokyo sttay. the room is small but clean, well equipped and full functioning as usual. i love the onsen at B1. free ice cube machine is available outside of onsen. convenient location, fast check in and check out....we had a comfortable stay.

The hotel is just a few mins walk from Shinjuku Gyoenmae station and about 7-8 mins walk from Shinjuku station. The hotel is a block from Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden which is full of huge lush trees.The hotel is fully equipped with necessary facilities, free wifi, hair dryer, amenities, freezer, alarm clock, towel, slippers, and bathrope. When you arrive at the reception, the front speak fluently English with friendly smile and welcomes you with an energy drink. You can also eave your luggage with them before and after your checking in/out times, too. There at the lobby, there's a self-check machines, restaurant and convenient restrooms available. It's a business-like hotel, so there're not many comfy sofa to sit at the lobby. The spa separating male and female opens for specific periods of hours but that is great enough to relax after a long walk of sightseeing or shopping. It's located at the underground where you can also find an ice maker and laundry machines. The room itself is not big but it's common when compared with other standard hotels in Japan. The hotel is situated in a quiet area. Although it's not far from Shinjuku busy station, you can still find local Japanese noodles and restaurants, coffee shops, and even Subway just 3 mins across the street from the hotel. And for shopping lovers, a 100 yen shop is just opposite the hotel!
