Amphoe Muang Khon Kaen, Khon Kaen, Thailand

review_body: I realise this is a budget hotel and considering the rooms have everything you need and the lovely onsen under the hotel, my rate was a really good one. when it comes to the arrival and departure experience however, they really drop the ball. I tried to check in at 1430 but was told room was ready but i need to wait until 1500. I spoke with the duty manager and she let me check in at 1445. The next day i requested late check out of 1130 instead of 1100 but was told there would be an extra charge. I totally get why hotels set arrival and departure times but here is a news flash for you-everyone has different travel plans. You have to learn to be flexable. Upon check out i wanted to store my luggage till my train at 1700. I was told they would only store it till 2pm. I only hope the managers and owners can learn from other budget/business hotels that it is possible to make guests feel helped while still maintaining profits and ensuring the smooth overall operations and keeping all guests happy. It is possible.

First time with this hotel but it was really worth the money. The hotel is new. Fully equipped with all the necessary stuffs. Big screen TV. Big window (comparing to any other hotels in the same range. No minibar. No complimentary water (This is Japanese hotel standard I think)The location is the best. Right in the heart of Kabukicho. Only 10 mins from Shinjuku JR Station and you can reach the subway within 5 mins walk (Shinjuku Sanchome) There are a few convenient stores around such as 7-Eleven and familymart. Don't worry if you will ever need anything. My reservation didn't include breakfast. But that wasn't a problem as there are selections of restaurants around there. The public bath is relatively cool. Not that big but still clean and nice. They have both indoor and outdoor as well. The lobby is quite small. Can be really crowded during check-in and check-out time. Thanks to the check-out machine that you can just drop the keycard and go. Will definitely comeback to stay here again.

Located in the center of Shinjuku with all the shops, lights and restaurants nearby. The room is tiny, we had to take turns opening our luggage. The pillow is weird cause it's so thin but to compensate the TV is enormous. But it's clean and comfortable .

We stayed here for one night on our first night in Japan. The room is small and so the bathroom, it's a common in Japan. But for you who bring big luggage and stay for long nights, this part is difficult. Hotel staffs were very nice and friendly. Location is excellent, just next to exit-1 of Shinjuku Gyoemmae Station of Tokyo Metro Marunouchi Line and just a walking distance from Shinjuku Station, restaurant and convenience store are located around the hotel. After an exhausting day just go down stair to public bath on basement floor and soak your body in hot water pool, very relaxing. Breakfast is ok for me, both japanese & western are provided. Basic amenities are also provided. Overall I would recommend this hotel.

This hotel was very nice, overall. It was beautifully decorated, very clean, and very organized. The sauna things were OK. They're not my thing, but they seemed pretty fancy.The staff was extremely friendly, and extremely helpful. They helped confirm my taxi to Haneda airport, and even left a note at my room to make sure everything was right. I appreciate this greatly. The location was excellent. You're only 5 minutes from the subway, and you're right by Shinjuku Gyoemmae. The bed was really comfortable. The bathroom was clean, and nice. I really liked the heated mirror that didn't fog up while showering. My only complaints are:1) The room is laid out so strangely. You only get a small aisle to walk in. There's a space at the end of the bed for the suitcase, but there's a corner wall notch that makes it hard to work with. If they'd put the bed in this little nook instead, there would be a better use of floor space! Also, the desk had a TV on it. If it were mounted on the wall, you'd have more desk space to stick things. It was a bit cramped. Not enough to ruin the experience, but enough to make you wonder why they didn't move the bed. I think it's simply because the bed has an electric headboard with lights + outlets, and it's sharing a circuit with the bathroom. If they put it on the other side, they wouldn't be able to do that. Oh well. If you stay here, don't bring a big suitcase. (If you're staying for about 3 weeks like we did, this part is difficult)2) There are only 2 washers and 2 dryers. It's a big hotel. Good luck.Overall, I liked the hotel, though. I would stay again.

Rooms are small, but so is all hotels room in japan... Very convenient location .... Hotel staffs were very nice and friendly... the bath house is pretty cool. I would definitely stay in this hotel again. I didnt give it a five star because my umbrella got stolen from the lobby :'''(. So be careful, donot leave your umbrella out in lobby even if its wet, take it with you to your room. Rest everything is A+

I came to this hotel expecting micro rooms and true enough, the room was pretty tight. Almost like being in a cruise ship. The bathroom is so tiny that when you shower you almost expect to be bumping into things and splashing the floor. There is not enough space to open a suitcase on the floor. But, unless you are claustrophobic this is a pretty decent hotel. The room is very clean. Basic amenities including slippers are provided which was not expected for the price I paid. It is in a quiet part of shinjuku but there are train stations Down the street and it is very accessible to tourist destinations. It is okay for an overnight stay.

Stayed at the APA Hotel Shinjuku-Gyoenmae from April 24 - May 3 2016.This is a great little hotel at an affordable price. Location: This is probably the best aspect of the hotel. A 10 minute walk from Shinjuku station. There's metro stops on either side of the hotel. There's a bunch of great little restaurants and ramen places within steps of the hotel and multiple stores (7-11, Family Mart) around too. It's right beside the Shinjuku Gyoen garden. It's just outside all the action, which we liked because it has a quieter vibe than if you were to stay in Kabukicho. Rooms: Rooms are tiny! We stayed for 9 days, so it was tough because there's no closet and we had to keep everything in the suitcase. We did expect this considering that it is Tokyo and the price we paid. If you're used to North American sized rooms, you'll be in for a shock. The bathroom is very small also but both the room and bathroom are clean. The bed is comfortable but the pillows are the thinnest pillows I have every experienced. You'll have to ask for a couple more if you don't like pillows thin. The room can get pretty hot and stuffy but the AC is quick to cool it down. We didn't eat at the restaurant because we didn't think it was worth the price. We chose to eat from the 7-11 when we were up early. Daily made sandwiches and other fresh foods and ramen bowls. There's a Freshness burger place that opens up at 7am that is really good, if you're into a burger for breakfast and a 24hr cafe type place that has breakfast too. There's also a small grocery store just down the block, which is cheaper than the convenient stores but it's not open 24hrs. There is a spa but we never ended up using it. I have tattoos and there is a sign about guests with tattoos so I didn't bother.Overall, our stay was very pleasant. The hotel is clean and the staff is friendly. The location is great if you don't always want to be in the action but still within walking distance. Room and bathroom is small but that was expected.I would stay here again but would probably spread out my stay with other places just for variety.

Stayed here for one night. Good hotel. Friendly and helpful staff. We stayed in a twin room and it was a decent size for Japan standards. Very clean and decent amenities in-room.Breakfast was good for what it was - standard buffet with a mix of Japanese and western choices.Check-in is at 3pm and don't expect to get your room any earlier than 3pm on the dot! - we arrived at about 2.30pm but no chance - the receptionist wouldn't even check if the room was ready. This is likely more to do with them following processes than being unhelpful, so never mind. We left our luggage and came back later.The location of the hotel is excellent. Shinjuku is a good part of the city to choose to stay in and the hotel is very close to a number of great bars, restaurants and shops. Also only about 10 minutes walk to Shinjuku station from where you can literally head anywhere.Recommended.

We had a smaller room in a Super hotel. This had room for a chair and a writing shelf. Perfect for a single person a bit cramped for two. Bed was comfortable extra pillows no problem. WiFi very good. Breakfast was Y800 not Y1800 as was on their web page.Trap was there are four APA hotels in as many blocks we were pointed to the nearest which was not the right one. We were then led up the garden path and found out that the the first four Japanese people we asked could not understand the map we were given by the hotel to our new destination 5 minutes away. We had plenty of time so the two hours it took us didn't matter. Dragging the suitcases did tire out a couple of 70+ tourist. There is a tendency for maps to not necessarily have North on the top. Please take note it can easily have you walking in the wrong direction.

An ok overnight hotel. Fine for business travellers but the tiny rooms make it difficult to stay longer than one night. There's barely enough room to open a suitcase so don't plan to unpack. On the plus side: It has washing facilities.It's perfectly located for downtown Shinjuku without being right in it. 10 minutes walk to the station. And the park at Gyonmae is just around the corner, and is a must-do. On the negative side: tiny rooms, very slow and inefficient lifts, cooked breakfast (western) is always cold, check-in is pretty inefficient.

I already knew that hotel rooms in Tokyo are very small, but this place gives a completely new meaning to what a small room really is. I couldn't even open my suitcase, and the bathroom was like an airplane restroom with a shower....luckily I only spent 1 night here.

We stayed for a week at the start of April. I quite liked the hotel BUT the rooms are very small, something which is normal for Tokyo, however I didn't expect it to be this small! With two suitcases a lot of stepping over was required. The double bed isn't a full width either so wouldn't suit people above average size. That said however the room was very clean and well stocked with toiletries and towels, kettle, Tv etc, even a small torch attached to the bed! But no wardrobe or shelves and drawers, just two hooks and a few coat hangers. The free spa was a big boost to end the day after a lot of walking and shopping etc and free to guests. I can't comment on the food as there are so many good value places to eat elsewhere at lower cost. I disagree with some of the negative comments about the staff, I found them polite even a little shy, maybe because they don't speak English confidently. the location is convenient for tourist and business persons alike, close to the subway and a 15 minute walk from the main Shinjuku station. There are plenty of places to eat and drink nearby and the area is very safe for tourists including families and solo travelers. For a central Tokyo hotel the price was reasonable.Overall a clean new hotel with good facilities in the price range that I would use again.

I was looking for a cheap hotel in Shinjuku area, and really didn't mind if the rooms were small, as long as the place was clean, decent, and had a great location. APA Hotel in Shinjuku-Gyonmae fits the bill to a T. It may have bigger rooms, I don't know, but for solo traveller like me, I was just looking for 1 single room.The room was very small, as expected. But amazingly compact in design and complete. This is Japanese efficiency of putting everything together in such a small space. I had a study table, a mini ref, a hospitality coffee and tea, and a giant flat screen TV (this was the only big thing)! The toilet was also amazingly compact, but well designed to fit everything you would need, including automatic bidet and nice hot shower. The toilet seemed like a pre-fabricated module plug into the room, and was spotlessly clean! As a single traveller, the small space is really just enough for one to move around, but who cares, I just need a place to sleep and shower. And I must say, the bed quality and duvet was superb--super soft, although the pillows were flat (Japanese style?). It also had an aircon so I switched it on so it doesn't get so stuffy. The reading lights and switches were also well located in such a small space. And must I say that the wifi was super fast! The location is also just less than 5 mins. walk to Shinjuku-Gyonmae subway (Maranouchi Line) which connects to Shinjuku main station (2 stops away) where you can connect to so many trains. Around the area is quite New Yorkish (quiet side) with Choco croque, Tully's Cafe, Freshness Burger, Coco Ichibanya, many Family Marts and 7-11's, and a big nice park behind. Very safe and clean neighbourhood. I didn't book for breakfast, as it was easy to eat out.It also has a free sauna and spa at the lower basement in case you want to use. I just took a look. It was a small but very clean. Hotel is quite new, it seems, and actually is a tall hotel, seemingly a business hotel for Japanese businessmen or salarymen, but also catering to tourists. Lobby is nice and decent, and check in was fast and efficient. This hotel would definitely be my go to hotel next time I go to Tokyo.

-Good location if you're cool with being in Kabukicho, which is a fun neighborhood, just not for kids after dark. Convenient to everything, and a lot in walking distance.You should be aware that the rooms are tiny and the elevators are slow. Worth mentioning, but I'd still return!

m1chaels
New York City, New York

review_body: Stayed one, unplanned, night in APA Hotel. I wasn't expecting much but was pleasantly surprised mostly because we paid very little at the last minute when all other hotels were either booked out or very expensive. Cons: -The room was very small and with one suitcase open there wasn't even room to open the main door.-The pillows were almost non existence, like a pancake, even with a second pillow it was not comfortable. -The hotel is a bit away from the centre of Shinjyuku but not too far to walk, even with suitcases. Pros:-Price-Room was modern, clean and quite. -Fast and reliable Wi-Fi For one night this hotel was ok but I would not stay any longer than that.

The hotel is very clean and new which is important to us and we enjoyed thay biggest concern was the room size. We rented a double room for a week... and we came with a week's worth of clothes. The room fit 2 single beds (each pushed against the opposite walls). This left about 18" left between the beds (no room for nightstands). At the foot of the beds was a builtin desk unit that had a small desk, the trash cans, a coffee maker and a refrigerator. Again, the distance between the foot of the bed and the desk unit was about 18". The only available space to fit a suitcase is blocking the door. In order to enter the door, one must first move the suitcase into the 18" gap between the beds, then open the door, then sneeze by the suitcase to get it back in front of the door. Okay, so you're thinking it's a bit tight... but that would be an understatement... there is no closet in the room so if you want something from your suitcase, then you must again guide the suitcase between the 18" gap between the beds and then put the suitcase on the bed in order to open it. Once you get your article of clothing from your suitcase, you must then re-close the suitcase and again guide it to the only available floor space (in front of the room door). This gets old really quickly especially when you are headed out and realize you need a sweater (from your suitcase). Renting a room without a closet, even a small closet, should be illegal and, at a minimum, should not be an adult hotel room. To solve the problem, we ended up renting a 2nd room across the hall. This way we could leave our suitcases open on the bed in the second room and simply use the 2nd room as a changing room. The bathrooms are sized accordingly... if you're a VERY small person you can take a shower semi-comfortably... if not, forget it. Ditto for sitting on the toilet. The newest fashion (at least in the US) is "tiny houses"... if you are a "tiny house" lover, then this is your place. If you just want a comfortable, reasonably sized room to sleep... there are better choices. We do want to point out that after 3 nights in the room, we were lucky enough to be able to move to the only deluxe room in the hotel (on the top floor) were there was a tiny closet, but at least we could consolidate our 2 rooms into one (with enough floor space to store and open the suitcases).

I moved here after an Airbnb disaster and could not have been more pleased. The room is quite small, but it was fine for a single traveller - if you are a couple, I'd recommend booking a deluxe room or the equivalent, if that's an option. Very clean, very new with excellent bed and sheets. Great toiletries as well. Location is good, far enough from Shinjuku station to avoid the insanity, but close enough to walk to. Park and subway are close by, and lots of nearby, low-key bars and restaurants. Check in and out was super easy, staff was friendly and no more English-challenged than any other hotel of this class. Great budget option, I really believe this hotel delivered terrific value. Would book again in a heartbeat.

Had a very bad experience. Too rooms were small to the point that we could barely fit our suitcases. No closets or drawers and we couldn't have the cases opened so in order to open one we had to close another. Front desk staff spoke very really English and were not very helpful (even with basic nearby directions).The only good thing was the location but I'd rather use mass transit at rush hour to get around than stay here again. Not to mention they made us pack everything and change rooms on our second day there and the only room available on our room type was a smoking room !!!Oh and did I mention they had ONE paper thin pillow on each bed and when I requested an extra pillow I was told they only had oriental style pillows which they were all out, so I was offered a bath towel to put under the one I had in the room !!!Horrible experience.DO NOT RECCOMEND!!

Although the room was very small and it felt like we were playing tetris for a week I would recommend this hotel. The bed was comfortable (I like flat pillows so no complaints from me), the room was cleaned and everything changed daily, the onsen was fantastic, the hotel has coin operated laundry and very friendly staff. I was surprised that many employees could not speak good English given the location but hey, we're in Japan! You can't beat the location.

This hotel opened in Shinjuku the summer of 2014. It's a spa hotel because there is a hot mineral bath included. Limited English is spoken by most of the staff as we noticed most were trainees when we checked in. Given that my wife speaks Japanese, we cannot comment on the poor service mentioned by others. Generally, it's easy to flag down a taxi on the street. Just don't expect 4 star hotel service when you're paying for 2.5 star. Japan is a very structured society so don't expect them to conform to foreign customs. A 15 minute brisk walk gets you to Shinjuku Station and shopping. Drink vending machine, ice machine, coin laundry, microwave and the spa are all located in the basement. Elevator access to the rooms is secured by your room card. The room is really compact at 11 sq.m. or 118 s.f.! Some may find it too claustrophobic! It's acceptable for a single person but for two, we would not stay anymore than a couple of nights. The amenities include fridge, kettle, A/Cond, humidifier, strong WIFI, BBC News in English. Our only complaint besides feeling like sardines, is the flat pillows and soft mattress like I was sleeping on a water bed. The Family Mart convenience store is across the street and to the east at the crosswalk.The hot bath spa is Japanese style so you need to observe the Japanese etiquette of no tattoos allowed (cultural issue), removing your footwear at the entrance, put all your clothes and bath towel in the basket in the change room (valuables can be put into the self locking lockers but please reset the combination back to 0-0-0-0 after use), enter the hot bath area and completely wash yourself in the washing stall and finally rinse yourself using the scoop before entering the pool. We're told that the bath water is mineralized and the temperature is about 39C. There's also an outdoor bath area. After leaving the hot bath, a quick shower is recommended to cool off. For a different lunch experience, you can try the gyoza eatery right across the street from the hotel. English menu is available. for Y590, you can enjoy a hearty set lunch which includes two choices of six gyoza each (we chose 6 fried with garlic and 6 boiled with garlic), seaweed broth and bowl of rice. They serve beer but i chose non-alcoholic beer for Y380. To keep it light, we shared that and an appetizer of fried burdock for Y290. That left us room for afternoon tea at the Takashimaya Dept. Store.

Very new hotel, which looks it: everything is super clean and still smells new. Yes, the room is small...this is normal in Tokyo especially for a not so expensive hotel. Those wanting a Western style and size room have to fork-out the thousands that a five star Western style hotel costs. We were treated well by the reception, the room was small but functional and super clean. The spa is an excellent place to relax after a long day. It is a great property, located in one of Shinjuku´s main avenues. Everything works efficiently. Loved our stay there.

My wife and I recently visited Tokyo for 6 dayd and stayed at this hotel for 5 nights.Location:Location was the only good thing and the reason that I gave it 2 stars. It’s close to the Shinjuku—gyoemmae station of Tokyo Metro and it’s about a 2 minutes walk. Also, it’s about a 10 minutes walk from the Shinjuku station.Room:We were expecting the room to be small but it was smaller than we anticipated. The size of the room is about 2 double size beds and we weren’t even able to open our luggages at the same time. The pillow was so flat that it felt like I was sleeping on my T-shirt.Facilities:There is only one restaurant and we didn’t try it as there are alot more choices around the hotel and at Shinjuku. There is one public bath at the basement but they refuse anyone with tattoos to enter. (Cultural issue so we respect that)Customer Service:There is absolutely no early check-in so just drop off your luggages and come back after 3 pm. Half of the staff at the front desk do not speak English and they refuse to do any service for you. My wife wanted them to simply make a call and interpret for us but the front desk refused to do so and their explaination was the receiver isn’t the same company as they are. We were furious about that as we are only asking them to be the translator. Another simple service that we asked was calling for a taxi in advance as we were leaving to the airport in the early morning. However, the front desk staff refused to call and said we can just walk out to the entrance and look for one. To be honest, I never been to any hotel in advance cities that would refuse to call us a cab. I m not sure if it was a cultural thing or the cab company wasn’t the same company as they are so they can perform such service.Conclusion:We will never stay at this hotel chain again due to their horrible service.

Arrived early from long haul flight at 6.00 am and straight to Shinjuku by Express trains. We fully understand the check time is 3.00 but the front desk never allows us to check-in even 2 minutes earlier even we have booked two rooms staying for 4 nights. This is pathetic and unacceptable. They hotels chain only cares for the local peoples. Travelers should beware of this kind of attitude. I totally do not recommend this kind of establishment to be patronized by westerners and will never stay here in the kind of hotels while leaving all those diry jobs to the outsider. Trypical.

Im staying at the hotel for a week.. the rooms are small, but the hotel is ok quality/price.On the other hand reception service is the worst i Ever seen,i never saw any urgency or customer service care at all.They charge us 1000 sad yens for early c/in (getting in our room at 14.00) once we spent 100.000 in 7 days. That was simply stupid. Staff who looked after us was hidenoby sato & a girl calles keiko and they were really rude & totally unhelpfull.U got no idea how to treat guest with good manners!! Management have big job to do training those bad profesionals!!I wouldnt recomend this hotel at all & i.ll go somewhere else instead for sure next time. C/in machine was pretty bad service as well, it look like we were in a petrol station buying peanuts & soda.It is simply useless, u have to be really bad profesional to give a service like this being 5/6 people x shift at reception.

They have the worst service ever. They refuse to book any restaurant for us, and they ask us to go to some travel agent to book the restaurants instead. Also, they refuse to call taxi for us evening when it's raining outside, and asked us to call go out and catch a taxi ourselves.

This is a fairly new hotel, having been built about 2 years ago. It looks stylish and modern on the exterior but has a small lobby and very small guest rooms. It was suitable for single travellers like myself who stayed for less than a week. There is no concierge or bell boy service available at this hotel. This means that you have to lug your own luggage up to your own room. One or two counter staff can speak and understand English well so it is a good thing as I really had problems trying to communicate with other counter staff. They were friendly and polite but had a weaker proficiency with English. The twin-share room I had was clean and well stocked with all toiletries. There is no wardrobe in the room, only 3 hooks on the wall for hanging your clothes. So I was literally living out of my suitcase for the 4 days that I was there. The bathroom basin tap and the shower tap are the same tap (because of space constraints) which is quite ingenious because it is both space-saving and technologically savvy. Get a room away from the lift lobby because it can get a little noisy. However, you may wish to note that the corridors are not well lit if you choose a room further away from the lift lobby. An upside is that the hotel employs English-speaking housekeeping staff from Nepal (yea, surprise surprise) who are helpful and friendly. I requested housekeeping not to clean my room on a certain day but when I returned back to the hotel late at night, housekeeping had left a bag full of new towels and toiletries for my use at my room door! It was a pleasant surprise to end an otherwise tiring work day.Breakfast at the hotel came with the hotel package (it would otherwise cost 1800 yen per person I think). It was a comprehensive Japanese breakfast buffet spread with rice, porridge, fruits, salad and some assorted miso, soba, meat and vegetable items to go with the carbs. There were buns as well but no live station (e.g. omelette station). You drop your breakfast coupon into a rattan basket placed at the entrance and then you are free to go find your own table and do your own stuff. There is only one waiter who will clear your table after you leave, so you may have a table full of plates at the end of your meal if you go on multiple trips to the buffet line. I like it that the hotel is located beside Freshness Burger, is opposite a couple of yakitori places, near a local supermarket, a 7-11 convenience store and a 100-yen shop. Most importantly, it is within walking distance (1 minute walk) to the Shinjuku-Gyoename train station! :)

The room was way too small, the instruction for the AC are only in Japanese, there is a very small bathroom, there are not drawers so I had to leave all my stuff in my suitcase.I have to say that it is in a good position and there is a very big TV screen.

Stayed here 3 nights. The hotel has loads of restaurants all around while at the same time its just far away enough down the road from all the noise of the shopping area. There are 3 Family marts all within 200m which are open 24hrs. There's also a Jonathans restaurant open 24hrs (but the serve food upto 2am only) good food there.Transportation- just 100m away from the shinjuku gyoenmae station & about 300-400m away from the shinjuku sanchome station which has better connectivity and transfer lines. Rooms are small as you'd expect for Tokyo. We were a couple. After opening our suitcase we'd actually have to step over it to get to the toilet so you get the idea. Warm, clean & cozy, I was not complaining as I Was out the whole day & used the room only to sleep. Facilities- coin dryer, washer & microbave in the basement for a very reasonable amount. 100 yen for 30min drying. Spa next to it for a Massage. Room cleaning is free but they dont change ur linen free. Complaints- Was not happy that they didnt clean my bath tub drain as it gets clogged easily due to the drain guard. Maybe the girl didn't understand me ? I don't speak japanese. Other than that, I had a pleasant stay. Im a stickler for hygiene & this place was pretty good.

Ver nice city hotel, small but pack. All item looks new, amenities was excellent various. As well as check in system very easy, convenience and fast. Location was only 3 minute walk from Subway station.

This hotel has a great location. I had arrived at Narita and took the NEX train to Shinjuku. This hotel is 2 stops away from Shinjuku station on the Marunouchi line. It's easier to reach the hotel by using Exit 1 at the Shinjuku Gyonmae metro station.It's a short 10-15 minutes walk to Shinjuku town centre. there are several restaurants close to the hotel.With regards to the hotel itself, the room is clean and basic. The room is small, but I've had even smaller room in London/NYC. To me, I think the room size is reasonable.I had breakfast daily at the hotel. It's cheaper to purchase a coupon beforehand for 1600yen. I had pre-purchase the coupons for the duration of my stay. However, my plans changed and I had to leave early. The staff were kind enough to refund me.Given the location of the hotel and the services provided, I would definitely return to this hotel again.

Nice clean hotel .. Good location and walkable to train Rooms are small but clean and comfortable and safe location. We stayed a week and would recommended this hotel. Shinjuku main train terminal is about 8-10 walk and make it easy to travel.

We couldn't really put our bags down that's how small the room was. However, the hotel makes up for it with its great location. Behind it is one of the best parks in town and it's very close to a major metro station. The Onsen was also a great feature.

Tried this hotel last April 2015 when we went to see the Cherry Blossoms. What we like about APA Shinjuku... It near a train station that is a major stop for train lines that goes to almost all majot attraction in Tokyo. Another is... Its a few steps from gyoemae park! For me the best place to view the Cherry Blossoms aside from Ueno park. Its also 10-15 mins walking distance to major department stores for shopping, and affordable restaurants. The staff tried their best to converse with us whenever we ask for information...Still... Some are lost in translation. However they more than made up for it with their friendly smile and eagerness to help. The room is small! So small that when you stretch your arms in ine part of room, you'll be able to reach wall from wall! But! Since we only stayed in the room to sleep, take a bath and change clothes and majority of our time was spent outside the hotel... The tiny room didn't bother us (well, when its packing time... Its get a little annoying! Haha). The bed is comfortable and the amenities is the bathroom is awesome!! They refill everyday! Our room was a a little warm for my liking. The breakfast is ok. Nothing special but worth being included to your booking as breakfast places outside the hotel is limited to 7/11 and family mart. All in all... We'll book this hotel again the next time we visit tokyo.

Small, but very nice rooms !!VERY BAD pillows in the rooms. Hotel looks in new condition, also has a public bath on the B1 floor. No public area to sit (a tiny one really) and no public computers to use, like many hotels in Tokyo have. Location is very good.

Slightly overprice budget hotel, however the room has what you probably need including hairdryer, air purifier, air deodorant and etc. Overall, still quite a nice place to stay if only you travel alone. What else can we expect for such price when your're in one of the most expensive cities in the world!

It's located a bit away from the centre of Shinjuku, though beside a metro station. Rooms are tiny, beds too soft and pillows too thin. But extremely clean, as is expected for Japan. There are better hotels in the area for the same price, like Sunroute Plaza Shinjuku.

This hotel is fairly new, having been set up in 2014. It is a small hotel without a concierge and porters, but the reception counter is always well-staffed with at least 3 staff. Although the English proficiency of each counter staff varies, they try their best to help their customers. For myself, I took a few tries to be clear on what I needed from them and also made sure that they could understand my requests. Check-in is at 3pm. Any earlier, you'd have to enquire at the counter to see if there are any rooms available and be prepared to pay additional $$ for the early check-in.Check-out is at 11am. It would be good to head downstairs earlier for check-out because the reception counter area is small and would not accommodate many large luggage with crowds. I stayed in a double room for 3 nights and it was comfortable and clean. There was a spray bottle of antiseptic which guests could use to disinfect any surfaces in the room. I found this useful and was surprised that there was virtually no speck of dust when I wiped the surfaces. When I ran into the housekeeper (a Nepalese man) the next morning, I asked if he could come to clear the rubbish in my room first as I was heading out. He willingly agreed and asked me what items I needed in my room so that he could top up for me. After cleaning up, he used a system wired into the room's plasma tv to update that he had cleaned the room. I was quite amazed with the technology used! I was pleasantly surprised to find a bag of new towels and toiletries set outside my room when I returned back late from a day of meetings. It turned out that the housekeeper did not enter my room as I had left the Do not Disturb sign on but he was kind enough to leave me spare towels and toiletries in case I needed a change. I think their housekeeping staff have done a great job! The pillows were a bit too hard and thin for my liking but I managed to stack 2 bath robes and 2 pillows together to make a new pillow for myself. This is manageable and not a big issue as everyone's pillow preferences differs. The quilt was very comfortable and warm. I could not really figure out the air-con and heater in the room but felt that the room was cool enough to sleep in without the heater turned on. At 18 degrees Celsius, the fall weather was comfortable. The heater is good for drying my towel and clothes worn for the day before, so that I could fold and pack them nicely back into my suitcase. Buffet breakfast was sumptuous with Japanese fare and some western food items like cornflakes and sausages. I had a good fill every morning though I think the fresh fruit selection could be improved. The waiter was polite and did not clear anything from my table until I was done with my meal. Even though my colleagues had finished earlier and left before me, the waiter waited patiently for me to finish before clearing everything on the table. The hotel is conveniently located near the Shinjuku-Gyoenmae train station and 7-11 is conveniently located in a minute's walk down the road. Freshness Burger is located just beside the hotel. Lawson's and Family Mart are nearby as well. There is also a supermarket (with a basement) that sells more fresh vegetables and fruits.

The room were small as usual (cause in city the city centre) but overall room facilities were complete. The room were clean and neat, the toilet are a little cramp. There's no control over the air conditioned, it was so hot during the stay. I have to open the air purifier to make it not so stuffy. The location for the hotel were good, there's a few convenient stalls just beside the hotel. The train station is also around the corner. There's some coffee shop at the end of the street that you can have your breakfast easily. The checkout was hectic, cause the elevator were small and many passenger check out in the same time.

The hotel is located near to a subway station, right next to the beautiful shinjuku gyoen. shinjuku main station is 2 subway stops away, but you can reach there by foot within 15minutes, passing by loads of shopping options (with some pretty good hidden restaurants!). I didn't really spend a lot of time in the room, so the room size wasn't a major problem for me. The hot bath located at the basement was a plus, but the pillows were real thin. Staff spoke minimal english. And if you expect to have a nice view from your room, you will be disappointed. You can barely open the window... :) Was the stay worth the money? Probably not, as I believe you may be able to get better rooms with similar price, just slightly off in terms of location.

We stayed in this hotel for 4 nights and it was TINY! By the last night, with all our shopping we had no room to put anything anywhere. There is no designated apace for clothes or for you to store your suitcase. There's a small suitcase rack opposite the bathroom. But if you put anything on it bigger than a carry on sized bag, the bathroom door won't open all the way. The bed is comfortable and actually the best bed we have slept on since coming to Japan but it is only accessible on one side which is really no good if a couple are sharing the room. The bathroom is small and the bathtub is smaller. It's designed to be sat in with your legs bent I suppose but using that is actually better than the shower as due to the poor design of the shower/bath combo, the bathroom floor floods no matter where you face the shower head. The TV is quite large and there is free WiFi. The air-conditioning seems to have one setting of blowing an absolute gale force at you. Negatives regarding the rooms aside, there's a coin laundry and trouser press in the basement and it's in a great location in Shinjuku as everything is within walking distance.

Ok, we saw the photos before we booked, but room was even smaller than we thought. As with everything Japanese, it was clean, and they did a decent job of maximising the space, but for us (a couple) with shopping bags and suitcases to open, it became a logistical nightmare. The restaurant downstairs is horrible.

We needed to stay an extra night in Tokyo as our plans changed, so had to move to another hotel . When searching hotels in the area we were quoted a rate, when we arrived an hour later to take up the rate we were informed that the rate had changed within that hour! I asked for the manager, as I was sure that the young reception staff were not understanding what I was trying to explain to them, a very young man informed me that the manager was on leave and he was the assistant manager. He spoke good English but was not able to keep to my original quote from the hour before as there was no-one who could give him the authority to do so...most bizarre. I believe that an assistant manager needs some life experience and empathy and of course some responsibility to make decisions in a managers absence. The room was clean, well fitted and had everything we needed. The wifi dipped in and out but was acceptable, when in! Location was brilliant. The hotels public bath was full of old Chinese men spitting, I spent all of 1 minute there. This hotel has huge potential but the junior staff with the very young supervisor without any authority left a bitter taste in my mouth.

TIP: DO NOR TAKE THE BREAKFAST. There's hardly any variety, and at rush hour (8:30 upwards) it gets cramped and the staff falls off its feet. It looks better earlier but if you look up close, it sloppy - the silverware are dirty, the food isn't fresh (the pancakes, some of the bread..). I'd recommend to get out of the hotel, take a left and walk 200 meters - there are two joints one next to the other, and they serve much better food for decent prices. The hotel is clean overall. But-The rooms are tiny. The windows don't open more than a book wide. The air-condition take air from the room and returns it back to the room, so it becomes bad at morning. We got a room that smelled like cigarette smoke, although we ordered a nonsmoking room. It was, as the Japanese made it, the hardest thing to change, but after a good argument they moved us.

Great location, nice breakfast, comfortable rooms, near subway station ! Family friendly! Enjoyed the 3 nights stay in shinjuku. 5 mins away from shinjuku downtown via train. Will definitely return to this hotel.

The Hotel Checkin is clean and smart, the check in staff are polite, helpful and efficient.The thing about Tokyo is property/real estate is really expensive, so you're not going to get a huge room on a budget. I booked a double room for one person, which was big enough for a four day stay.The breakfast buffet was a comprehensive mix of Western and Japanese fayre.As appears customary in Japan the beds are rock hard, it took me a few days to get comfortable with this concept. This really was my only complaint. The room was well finished clean and tidy, the bed linen was cotton of good quality and changed daily.In the basement is an Onsen (Japanese Spa) - do take time to familiarise yourself with the etiquette of the facility. The people are so friendly and polite, you really wouldn't want to cause offence.Outside the the hotel is less than a minute from the underground/metro/subway etc. The main Shinjuku railway station is about ten mins walk away. On the street there are number of good reasonably priced bars serving a mix of Western and Japanese meals and bar snacks. A little further away near the main station is the slightly 'racey' entertainment district.For my first stay in Tokyo I found the hotel made everything as easy as it could be.

Terribly small rooms with no day light and very basic equipment ; service just average, normal breakfast, but in overcrowded room : long queue ...Definitely not worth the price, despite very good location.

The hotel was nice, however very small, there was no room to fit our suitcases. The bed wasn't the best and the pillows were about 1/4 of the thickness as a normal pillow... The location was good a short walk to Shinjuku station and restaurants.

Nice hotel, excellent location next to the Shinjukugyoenmae subway station. Room is very small, but spotless. Bathroom was surprisingly spacious (relatively). Breakfast buffet is just ok, actually is bad... Special bonus is the onsen in the basement floor - a real treat after a long day!

I regret not booking Tokyo sooner, when all the hotels I like were still available. When it came to confirming there were only a few hotels left, one was Apa Hotel Shinjuku Gyoenmae a corporate hotel that makes you feel like a number and not a client. The hotel is well positioned in Shinjuku, really close to two good metro stations and to many shops and restaurants, but the positives end here. The staff seemed to be all trainees with very little knowledge or intuition of what foreign tourists want.English was barely spoken in the hotel, we had to rely on google translator. Overall, the staff seemed unhelpful, at times I felt that not speaking English was just an excuse. Even when we asked for their help to book a restaurant in Japanese they were very reluctant to do it and kept on giving excuses that were ridiculous! We couldn't speak Japanese and APA Shinjuku is not the right place to stay if you don't speak Japanese, or if you like hotels to be stylish with helpful staff.The hotel is clean and that is all I can say. The breakfast is OK, nothing more.Should I visit Tokyo again I will make sure I don't book another APA Hotel!

The room was the smallest we have ever stayed in and this is my 3rd trip to Japan. The hotel looks lovely and is very clean and tidy - however that is where the positives stopped. The room could not cater to two suitcases. Only one person could move around at any one time, so the other had to sit on the bed or in the chair provided. The air conditioning did not work as it was their spring and they had the heater on - set at a regulated temperature that could not be adjusted. We were not the only ones asking for this to change while we were there. Their solution was to open the window; which we did only to have the noise from the streets and the sirens keeping us awake at night. The following day they placed a sign in the lifts asking guests not to ask for it to be adjusted - as I say, we were not the only ones who had this issue. During the weekend there was a great breakfast selection on offer - during the week, although good options remained available, the options were reduced. This is not a hotel I would recommend unless traveling on your own. We were very, very disappointed and it was not a cheap hotel!

Having never travelled to Tokyo before we left our accommodation in the hands of our travel agent who recommended APA Shinjuku as a good quality, cheap hotel that is close to transport, restaurants and attractions. The hotel is very clean offering a good variety for breakfast but the rooms are tiny - so be prepared. Two Aussies travelling with luggage makes moving around the room an experience often seen on National Geographic TV. The location is excellent and the staff very helpful and friendly. Make sure you visit the Shinjuku Gardens located just behind the hotel - especially during Cherry Blossom season......stunning! We would have no hesitation staying here again.

The room was very small (both bathroom & bedroom). However, the room seemed new and clean. There was very good variety for breakfast, and the hotel has an excellent location very close to the station in one of the nicest parts of Shinjuku!

This is the worst hotel we have stayed in 3 trips to Japan. The room is 3 metres x 3 metres and the bathroom is within that space. The air conditioning unit is controlled remotely and if this is not to your liking the hotels solution is for you to open the window. Thd bed is so soft you roll off the side. The only redeeming factors are its location and the buffet breakfast if you can get a table to sit at.

Ideally situated close to two different Metro stations this hotel was perfect for exploring Tokyo.First ever hotel in Japan, and was different to any other hotel I've used.I've stayed in in any other country. The room was tiny but well laid out with a very comfortable bed and the space aged Japanese toilet. I was not sharing the room therefore I found my double room worked for me. At 1.73m tall and approx 90kilos using the tiny tub was going to be a problem was my initial thought: wrong, it was easy.I would recommend this hotel, however if two sharing a room with several suitcases it may present more problems.As an experience, I love it.

There are so many of these hotels around Tokyo that our driver actually took us to the wrong one the first time. Once we found the correct hotel, there was some miscommunication as to how the rooms had been paid. Apparently, you can't pay in advance so we had to have a company credit card limit increased to cover the cost of 3 rooms. Once this was taken care of, the hotel was fairly pleasant. The rooms were quite small with my bed literally touching wall to wall from head to toe. The view from my room was nice though. The bathroom was ok, but the shower, even with the curtain, soaked the floor every morning. The breakfast in the restaurant was quite good with a variety of Western and Japanese style breakfast items. The elevators were a bit slow and hitting one button to call an elevator didn't actually signal all 3 available elevators. Also, for some reason, there is no roof in the hall ways so on the higher floors in February, it was quite cold outside the room, and when it rained, some of the railings were wet. The location of the hotel was great with only a 5-10 minute walk to Shinjuku station and from there you can get anywhere in and around Tokyo.

I stayed in the hotel during Tokyo Marathon. I need a place which was not to far from the start point which was Shinjuku Station and affordable for me. I realized for big event, all hotels near Marathon start would be very expensive. I'm open minded person I didn't expect a lot when I travel. The room was small, it's Japanese standard room for one person. I'm 5'11, so I feel bit tight; since I spent lots of time outside the room, I'm totally fine. BTW, I tried oxygen capsule, so my room is much larger and better. I like the deep bathtub so I could try Japanese style bath. I tried the breakfast on my last day. All you can eat for ¥1800. The breakfast is mixed for Japanese and Western food. I just tried the Japanese breakfast. Yummy. Front desk are very helpful and friendly. Even though they speak little English. I don't mind. After check out I could leave my suitcase there. Overall I had very good experience.

This hotel is fairly new and in a great position 100 metres from the metro. restaurants,bars and shopping abounds here so you can't go wrong with that, however the rooms are tiny and expensive for what you get. We came here to spend a few nights after visiting the snowfields and had 2 suitcases and 2 in cabin bags...our room was the length of the double bed by 2 1/2 metres. our bags sat behind our entry door and we had to squeeze past each time we left or returned to our room.Bathroom is also tiny and is a plastic pop out 2 metres by 1 1/2 metres so your face and knees almost rest on the door while you are on the toilet and bangs on your suit cases as you enter and leave the bathroom. Wallpaper, curtains and carpet are new and modern and tastefully done.The bed is ok but the pillows are very flat and uncomfortable. Only 1 each is allowed.Breakfast is good but had to ask staff a few times to replenish items on the buffet, which you have to line up at the door for. The spa is wonderful and I found that better for a soak and showering than our bathroom.My friend stayed at the Hilton for a $100 cheaper per night and had a great room. So consider the size when booking. Staff struggle with English and not overly friendly but do get the job done.

We stayed at this hotel for 8 nights. The clerks in the lobby were so helpful and a couple of them understood English. My brother lost his wallet in Kyoto and the lady at the counter wrote in japanese what we need to take to the police station. The rooms are very clean, small, but clean. The maids were very helpful when we needed anything. This hotel in the middle of Shinjuku and walking distance from the Train station and many restaurants. I would highly recommend this hotel to family and friends

Very good location, close to metro and Shinjuku sites. Rooms are standard size for Tokyo with a deep bath. If you turn up early it's 1000 yen per hour early. Don't miss the hot bath in the basement for a proper soak. Breakfast buffet is fine.

You may want to read my reviews of other Tokyo hotels to see what my basis for comparison is.We were pushed out of our usual hotel(s) into this new one in a quieter neighborhood of Shinjuku because we booked last minute during Christmas. The hotel is new and in great shape. It's very Japanese so you need to be ready for that, in spades. Provided you are, it is in fact a very nice place. It's only real drawbacks are size (it really is tiny) and the rather quiet and farther out location is a good 10-15 minute walk to Shinjuku station. o There is a nice onsen in the basement, which is free (unusual in Japan where there's typically a small charge for just about anything). It isn't big (shocker) and gets heavy use during peak times, so it can be a little crowded. Nice Japanese touch though.o About 80% of their guests are Japanese and the rest, other Asian. I saw zero European or other flavour guests during our stay.o The standard of English of the front desk is better than I had expected, but not as good as larger Japanese hotels in busier districts. It was certainly adequate to basic hotel tasks like checking in and getting another pillow, though. o It is about a 15 minute walk from Shinjuku JR into a residential neighborhood, but the area still has a bunch of nice restaurants and a lot of convenience stores too. It's not smack in Kabuki-cho in other words, but you still have everything basic you need around it. The nearest Subway line station is Shinjuku-Gyoenmae, which is like 2 mins in the other direction and would be very convenient except that line doesn't actually go anywhere. o This hotel is BUSY. The lobby is small, and mobbed. Check in and out was efficient but there were still at least 10 people in line all the time. o The rooms are TINY. Very nice, with excellent sheets, towels, bedding, etc. But the smallest I have ever stayed in. The double is about 150 sq ft, not more. For two people to sleep, you have to be in an embrace all night, more or less. If you are two sharing the room, I would say if you have a combined waist measurement for the two of you of more than 65", forget it. Seriously. Or large luggage x 2. One big bag and one small is as much as you can do. 2 large bags would be impossible. For a single person it would be ideal, unless you're Yao Ming or something. o The bathroom is small but for some reason is not a problem. Everything works out nicely, even a deep soaking tub, oddly. But the smallness of the bedroom really broods for two. o TV is predictably Japanese only. Great wifi, free fast and no palaver. Simple login. Unlimited devices.o Very odd pillows are standard. Kind of like one of those sponges for dish-washing that have a mesh over foam rubber. XL size, thin. Unusable for sleep. They will change them for better ones though if you ask and are willing to endure a bit of a palaver. o Window actually opens, which was nice in a Japanese winter to offset the nuclear heating. o The price is reasonable at about a third cheaper than our usual large hotels right on the stations. I would guess out of season you can probably get it for about ¥12-15k or so, which would be great value. I would stay here again if alone and on business. The appointments are in fact better then the other 3 large central hotels we usually use. It is only the rather remote location and the microscopic rooms that deter.

Unfriendly beyond rude staff discriminate between local japanese and foreigner tourist, the room is basically fit for a dog, a dog box size of room. I don't understand why other people give this hotel a good review. It was the worst service I ever recieved and I didnt expect this service from a hotel in Japan, by the way we paid 400 US during our stay at the new year. So it wasn't cheap. I warn you people just look for somewhere else..

They have a good sizable spa area with sauna, outside tabs and outside area to cool down. In the middle of Shinjuku area, this is a good find and I loved it. It's cost performance is reasonable, too. Very close to Shinjuku Gyoen so you can just pop around to see this wonderful park. You can walk to stations within 10 minutes. If you are foreign and wanting to use Japanese spa, then please please please respect their local culture by learning the rules of how to take bath and how to behave: it has been really putting off Japanese people when foreigners are not respecting the local culture. Bathing area is where the Japanese come to relax, not expecting people talking loud and dominating the atmosphere.

A few things that are bothersome for travelers when looking for hotels in Tokyo.1. location. it is difficult to workout the chome system for foreigners, you either rely on google-map, or pick somewhere with landmarks, or somewhere right next to the metro exit. And this is it, the apa hotel shunjuku gyoenmae is 1minute walk from the metro exit, along a big street hard to miss.2. small rooms. I am sorry, rooms will be small unless you are prepared to pay 3-400USD/night, or in a location that is so off-center you waste time commuting. so yes, the apa-hotel has standard tokyo citycenter room size, once you open your luggage there will be no room to stand. However that is "normal" in this location. For a bigger room, try Hilton, Hyatt, Sheraton, but they are all at painful locations, locations where it is painful to walk, but ridiculous to get on a cab. For big rooms right in front of an accessible station, try Shangri-la Tokyo right at the door of Tokyo Tokyo station.3. an average bed in an average Japanese hotel is hard. some people grew up with it and are fine. I am not. for a Sealy mattress, you will have to go for SPG group... or the APA group! for SImmons, you will have to go for other expensive options. so I have to say that the mattress at APA hotel is the best bed for this price. other similar options include Super Hotel (not very good locations for Tokyo, unless Chiba)4. tiny bathrooms. sorry the bathroom is tiny, all plastic, earthquake-proof; but the tub is slightly modified, and managed to fit a 5'9" guy weighing 225lbs reasonably well5. language problem. the staff here had no problem with English. and the checkout was automatic, just like a train ticket vending machine.6. wanting to try an onsen but donn't know how and where. well, there is an artificial onsen right at the basement of the hotel, don't know the how-to's? ask a staff.All in all, I am very happy with the stay at APA hotel, and would highly recommend this.

The hotel is clean and in a good location and staff are friendly. However it really is tiny. I mean not suitable for 2 people in the same room unless you take turns walking in the room. Good for someone just sleeping in the hotel while out to discover or for business but there is no hanging out or relaxing space in the room.

On business for two nights. Booked the single room to save money and it was indeed tiny room, albeit with a double bed. No room for a suitcase, no iron in the hotel at all so a little problematic to get the wrinkles out of the shirts for work. Capsule like bathroom and average breakfast, but it was spotless and comfy bed. Definitely targeted to the Japanese market so little English spoken and TV instructions all in Japanese. However as I said, it's fine for a couple of nights and somewhere to put your head down at a decent price for the area. Handy to metro station and loads of bars and restaurants in the area.

I've just enjoyed four nights in this hotel in Shinjuku, Tokyo. Three of us stayed here and all agreed that it was more of a 4 star hotel than the 3 stars that its sold as. It opened in July and everything is still new and spotless. We booked single rooms which were pretty much as expected - not large rooms but ideal for one person - and with great facilities i.e. mini-fridge, heater (not needed), adjustable air-con, free wi-fi in the room, beautiful comfortable bed although the pillows took a bit of getting used to. For the Sat - Tues period we paid a total of Yen 46,000 - about £65 per night which included a hot and cold buffet breakfast (English and Japanese food) and access to the spa. The hotel is easy to get to from Narita airport - just get the Narita Express (N'Ex) to Shinjuku from the airport for Yen 1500 (Yen 3000 for the return journey). The journey takes about 80 minutes. Shinjuku, Shinjuku-Sanchome and Shinjuku-Gyoemmae stations / metro stops are all close with the latter only two minutes walk from the hotel. Around the hotel are a multitude of shops, department stores, restaurants and bars. Hotel staff - and everyone we met in Tokyo - were all very friendly and eager to help. Their level of English varies but far exceeds my Japanese! Most places used english as a second language. The metro has signs and announcements in both Japanese and English. The area appeared safe and we noticed that locals left handbags and cameras unattended on tables. Beware in Kabukicho of following touts into bars as these can be a complete rip-off. This is a great hotel and I thoroughly enjoyed my stay there and would defintely use it again. There's loads to do in Shinjuku and its easy enough to get to Shibuya, or the centre of Tokyo within 30 minutes by metro.
